entry.author: Enrique Andres Pretel
entry.headline: Exxon to cede oil project ops to Venezuela by May
entry.body:
CARACAS (Reuters) - Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) plans to hand operations of a multibillion-dollar oil project to the Venezuelan state before a May 1 deadline imposed by President Hugo Chavez, industry sources told Reuters on Thursday.

Chavez this week signed a decree for the government to take a majority stake in four heavy crude upgrading projects in the Orinoco basin by May 1 as part of a nationalization drive toward Cuba-inspired socialism.

The move shows Exxon, the world's largest company, complying with Chavez's order to cede control of the Cerro Negro project despite doubts over whether private companies will in fact meet Chavez's ambitious deadline.

Energy authorities in 2006 extended an initial deadline to take control of oilfields operated by private and foreign oil companies, which operated the fields for three months as negotiations continued.

Exxon Mobil has always been expected to take the toughest line with Venezuela, according to industry analysts, who have cast doubts over whether PDVSA has the technical capacity to run the complex operations valued at an estimated $30 billion.

"Exxon is preparing to hand over operations by May 1, in line with Chavez's instruction that after May 1 Exxon is not the operator of Cerro Negro," said an industry source, who asked not to be named because he was not allowed to speak for the record.

Another industry source described an internal memo signed by the president of Exxon's Venezuela division saying the company was preparing a transition before May to give state oil company PDVSA control of the project.

Cerro Negro is a joint venture between BP Plc (BP.L), PDVSA and Exxon Mobil, which operates the project through a subsidiary. Exxon did not respond to an e-mail requesting comment on the issue.

The four Orinoco projects provide nearly a quarter of all oil production in Venezuela, according to the United States -- which relies on the South American nation for about 11 percent of oil imports.

Chavez, a Cuba ally and Washington foe, in January ordered the government to accelerate the takeover of the projects amid a broad nationalization push that led to quick takeovers last month in the telecom and electricity sectors.

TOUGHER NEGOTIATIONS

But analysts say Venezuela faces much tougher negotiations for the Orinoco projects, which turn low-quality tar-like oil into about 600,000 barrels per day of valuable synthetic crude that can be processed by traditional refineries.

Other companies involved in the projects, which include Conoco Phillips (COP.N), Chevron Corp. (CVX.N), France's Total (TOTF.PA) and Norway's Statoil (STL.OL), have expressed doubts that they will be able to meet the deadline.

"We have had no meaningful discussions with the Venezuelan leadership," said Conoco Phillips CEO James Mulva on Thursday in conversations with reporters.

Chavez has used oil revenues to finance a massive social development program for the nation's poor majority that helped him win a landslide reelection victory last December.

But critics say the heavy spending has cut into much-needed investments in the oil sector and insist the takeover of the Orinoco projects could damage the complex operations.

(With additional reporting by Brian Ellsworth and Saul Hudson)

entry.headline: New Univision CEO may ease bickering with Televisa
entry.body:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - The arrival of a fresh face at the helm of Univision may help improve relations between the U.S. broadcaster and Mexican partner Televisa after years of fighting over royalty rights and management direction.

Univision Communications Inc. named advertising industry veteran Joe Uva as chief executive on Tuesday, ahead of a private equity buyout of the U.S. Spanish-language company next month.

Uva's appointment "opens an opportunity for the relationship to start afresh," Jose Cancela, principal at consulting firm Hispanic USA in Miami, told Reuters on Wednesday.

Relations between Univision and Grupo Televisa have deteriorated in recent years amid legal battles over Univision's management, content rights and royalties.

In 2000, Televisa committed to provide Univision with its top entertainment and sports shows for a 17-year period. While the Mexican company receives royalty payments, last year they accounted for less than 5 percent of total sales of 37.932 billion pesos ($3.5 billion).

Televisa's programming has given Univision a competitive edge against NBC's Telemundo, but its share of the pie is rather small and the company has not been shy about its intention to boost its presence among U.S. Hispanics.

"Televisa gives an out-of-proportion value to what it gets from the Univision deal," Cancela said. "Univision without Televisa is Telemundo."

Univision has about 80 percent of the U.S. Spanish-language market, and Telemundo most of the rest.

A Televisa source told Reuters on Tuesday that the Mexican company hoped Uva could strengthen links between the two broadcasters.

Uva's proven credentials in the advertising world are expected to pull in more advertising dollars for Univision thanks to the high television ratings it delivers.

In some key time slots, Univision has notched stronger viewership than media giants like ABC, CBS, NBC or Fox.

Uva "has got great relationships with the advertising community and that's what still going to be needed for long-term growth for Univision," said analyst David Joyce with Miller Tabak + Co. LLC.

Uva, who will take his new post in April, was OMD Worldwide's president and CEO. He is also a former president of Time Warner Inc.'s Turner Entertainment Group Sales.

Like his predecessor, Jerrold Perenchio, Uva is not a Spanish speaker, media reports said.

"But he speaks the most important language that Univision lacks: the access to advertisers who are not currently spending in the Hispanic market," Cancela added.

Uva's appointment is the latest step in a year-long shake-up at Univision, which included a bidding war between Televisa and other private equity investors, Perenchio's announced departure, and the arrival of new owners.

In September, Televisa threw in the towel in a bidding war for Univision after it refused to sweeten a $12.3 billion offer from a rival group of equity firms and media mogul Haim Saban. The acquisition is to be completed in March.

After its defeat, Televisa said it was selling its 11 percent stake in Univision.

Televisa local shares were off 13 pesos at 61.03 pesos on Wednesday afternoon, while its New York-traded stock rose 11 cents to $27.34. Univision shares rose 6 cents to $35.96.

($1 = 11.1635 pesos)

Reuters/Nielsen

entry.headline: EU warns Microsoft of possible further fines
entry.body:
(adds details, background)

BRUSSELS, March 1 (Reuters) - The European Commission warned Microsoft (MSFT.O) on Thursday it faced further fines in its antitrust case for seeking unreasonable prices from software makers for interoperability information.

The latest formal charges could lead to new fines against the U.S. software giant, the Commission said in a statement.

The Commission found in 2004 that Microsoft violated European Union antitrust rules by failing to give information to other makers of small-business servers needed to compete with Microsoft's own products.

Microsoft has said it would be charging for interoperability information because it was based on its own innovative work.

"The Commission's current view is that there is no significant innovation in these protocols," European Competition Commissioner Neelie Kroes said in a statement.

"I am therefore again obliged to take formal measures to ensure that Microsoft complies with its obligations," she said.

Microsoft has four weeks to reply to the charges.

The Commission rejected 1,500 pages of information provided by Microsoft.

It said it is still reviewing whether information submitted earlier to help software makers develop programmes that run smoothly with Microsoft's Windows operating system is complete and accurate.

Microsoft has appealed the original 2004 decision to a European court which is due to decide on the case this year.

((Reporting by David Lawsky; editing by William Schomberg; Reuters messaging david.lawsky.reuters.com@reuters.net; e-mail david.lawsky@reuters.com; +322-287-6811. Brussels newsroom)) Keywords: MICROSOFT EU/WARNING

entry.headline: Novell says Microsoft Linux certs topped $73 mln
entry.body:
BOSTON, March 1 (Reuters) - Novell Inc. NOVL.O Chief Financial Officer Dana Russell said that Microsoft Corp. issued more than $73 million worth of certificates for his company's Linux software during the fiscal first-quarter.

Novell will book that revenue over one to three years, depending on the term of each certificate, he said in an interview.

Microsoft sells Novell's Linux software to its customers in the form of certificates that they can exchange for Novell products under the terms of a partnership that was signed late last year.

In Novell's fiscal first quarter, which ended Jan. 31, revenue from those Microsoft certificates accounted for "a very small amount" of the sales that Novell booked, Russell said.

For the full year, he said he is "confident" that the certificates will account for more than $20 million in revenue.

entry.headline: Russian ecology watchdog to check Exxon Sakhalin-1
entry.body:
MOSCOW (Reuters) - Russia plans to start new checks on the Exxon Mobil-led Sakhalin-1 oil and gas project at the end of March, an environmental watchdog official said on Thursday.

Oleg Mitvol, deputy head of the Russian environmental agency RosPrirodNadzor, said the examination of the scheme on the Pacific island of Sakhalin would focus on how Exxon and its partners fulfill their environmental obligations.

"We plan to start the first part of the checks -- the paperwork -- on March 28. About a month after that, probably in May, the second part -- the checks on the ground -- is to begin," Mitvol said.

Previous inspections, conducted last year by Russia's technical standards agency, RosTekhNadzor, delayed full scale exports from the project by several months after it said Exxon needed to do more work at its Pacific export terminal.

Mitvol led inspections of Royal Dutch/Shell's neighboring Sakhalin-2 oil and gas scheme last year, and analysts said his actions helped persuade the group to sell a controlling stake to Gazprom for $7.45 billion.

The pressure quickly subsided after the sale.

Gazprom's Sakhalin-2 deal was one of the latest examples of the Kremlin's desire to regain control over all big projects in top industries.

But analysts say a similar outcome is unlikely at Sakhalin-1, where the project also includes powerful state-controlled Russian company Rosneft as a partner.

Exxon's Sakhalin and BP's venture TNK-BP remain the last large foreign-led energy projects in Russia.

Mitvol also said his agency would start another inspection of French company Total's Kharyaga oil project in Russia's Arctic on March 12.

"Previous checks, conducted last year, discovered some problems in fulfilling the licensing agreement, so we will check whether they have been settled," he said.

entry.headline: EU warns Microsoft of possible further fines
entry.body:
BRUSSELS (Reuters) - The European Commission turned up the pressure on Microsoft (MSFT.O) on Thursday, warning the U.S. software giant of new fines and accusing it of serial defiance of an antitrust ruling made nearly three years ago.

The Commission said Microsoft has set unreasonably high prices that discourages would-be competitors from making server software, while Microsoft continues to grab market share.

"In the 50 years of European antitrust policy, it's the first time we've been confronted with a company that has failed to comply with an antitrust decision," the Commission's competition spokesman Jonathan Todd said.

Todd said the continuing dispute, almost three years after the Commission found Microsoft abused the dominant market position of its ubiquitous Windows operating system, was solely due to the company's behavior.

"You have to look at their attitude faced with other antitrust authorities in other jurisdictions. This is a company that apparently does not like to have to conform with antitrust decisions," Todd told a news conference.

But Microsoft General Counsel Brad Smith said the fines and troubles it faced in Europe were unique.

"We have been complying with antitrust rulings on five continents for 15 years and yet we are not experiencing these kinds of issues or this type of process anywhere else," he told reporters in a conference call.

Microsoft has four weeks to reply to the charges and is entitled to a hearing.

PATENT PROTECTED

In March 2004, the Commission imposed a record 497 million euro ($657 million) fine on Microsoft and ordered it to change its business practices, ruling the company failed to give information to other makers of small-business servers needed to compete with Microsoft's own products.

Microsoft has said it would charge for interoperability information because it was based on its own innovative work and protected by patents.

But the Commission said on Thursday competitors give away such software whether or not it is patented.

"The Commission's current view is that there is no significant innovation in these protocols," European Competition Commissioner Neelie Kroes said in a statement.

"I am therefore again obliged to take formal measures to ensure that Microsoft complies with its obligations," she said,

Microsoft said the Commission was trying "to regulate the pricing of our intellectual property on a global basis and not just within the EU".

It said a study showed its prices were 30 percent below the market rate. The assertion in a 1,500-page submission was rejected by the Commission as unfounded.

No Microsoft rival has bought the interoperability data because it is too expensive, the Commission's Todd said.

He said Microsoft's market share of small-business server software has grown to 75 percent while it defies the Commission.

Todd said additional daily fines for overpricing the protocols could be backdated to December 16, 2005. Microsoft could face additional fines of hundreds of millions of euros.

They would be in addition to the 280.5 million euros the company was fined last July for failing to give clear instructions on how to use the protocols, and the 2004 fine.

The Commission said it is still reviewing the latest versions of the instructions.

Microsoft has appealed against the original 2004 decision to a European court which is due to decide on the case this year.

A Commission spokeswoman was asked by reporters if the Commission would still work with Microsoft in innovation given its failure to respect EU rules. "I think different aspects you mentioned are not affected by today's decision," she replied.

entry.headline: Disney plans major expansions to Walt Disney World
entry.body:
LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Walt Disney Co. (DIS.N) on Thursday said it was planning two big expansions to its Walt Disney World theme park in Florida, including a 900-acre luxury resort and a commercial district outside the gateway entrance.

In a statement, Disney said the luxury resort would be anchored by a Four Seasons hotel FSH.TO FS.N and would include an 18-hole golf course and vacation homes.

Work on the luxury resort could begin this year, and the hotel is forecast to open in 2010. It will be located along the northeast border of Walt Disney World on the current site of the Eagle Pines and Osprey Ridge golf courses.

In addition, on the western edge of the park, Disney said it would build a pedestrian-friendly development with hotels, stores and restaurants. That project, which is in the design stage, will be comparable in size to Disney's Animal Kingdom.

The development, which will center around a retail village, will be built in phases over 8 to 10 years, Disney said.

Disney shares were up 13 cents, or 0.38 percent, at $34.39 in mid-day trade Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange.

entry.headline: Chevron says authorized sale of Nerefco refinery
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 1 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N), the second-largest U.S. oil company, said it has authorized the sale of its 31 percent stake in the Nerefco refinery in the Netherlands.

In its annual report filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday night, the company said that the sale was still subject to the signing of a sales agreement and obtaining necessary regulatory approvals.

The company would not disclose any further details such as possible buyers or deal value, but spokesman Don Campbell said Chevron should have something more to say in the near term.

Chevron also said it expects to record a gain upon the close of the sale.

The 400,000 barrels per day Nerefco refinery is a joint venture with BP Plc. (BP.L)

entry.headline: Pfizer announces Maraviroc, significantly reduces viral load, in combination therapy across range of treatment-experienced patients
entry.body: Coannounces 24 week analysis showed that approx twice as many patients receiving maraviroc with an optimized background regimen achieved undetectable virus in the blood than if an optimized regimen was given alone. The new data, presented at the 14th Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections (CROI), support the accelerated United States and European regulatory review of maraviroc as a treatment for patients infected with HIV that is "CCR5 tropic," -- enters immune cells by a receptor known as CCR5. In addition, patients receiving maraviroc and an optimized regimen saw an increase in CD4 cells nearly twice that seen in those receiving optimized regimen alone.

entry.body: Co announces the sale of its holdings of Swiss Re Common Shares and reaffirmed its first quarter and full-year 2007 EPS. Terms of the sale include GE selling 16.65 million shares of common stock at a price of 104 Swiss francs per share. entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Poland's PGNiG buys Norway gas stake from Exxon
entry.body:
(Adds details)

WARSAW, March 1 (Reuters) - Polish natural gas monopoly PGNiG PGNI.WA said on Thursday it would buy a 15 percent stake in three exploration licenses from ExxonMobil (XOM.N) to gain access to natural gas off Norway's coast.

PGNiG's will pay $360 million for the stake, giving the Polish company partial access to around 35.8 billion square metres of natural gas deposits.

Poland's conservative government hailed the deal as the first step towards reducing Poland's dependence on Russian supplies.

"This is good news that we will gain access to gas deposits and it is also good news from the point of view of diversifying supplies," Poland's Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski told a news conference.

PGNiG plans to begin extracting natural gas and crude oil from the Skarv and Snadd fields in 2011.

The company's share of investment costs will be around $600 million, PGNiG said.

British Petroleum (BP.L) is the direct operator of the fields and other partners include Shell (RDSa.L), Statoil (STL.OL) and Norsk Hydro (NHY.OL)

PGNiG imports more than half of Poland's 13 billion cubic metres in annual gas consumption, most of it from Russia.

It has long sought to diversify supplies, increasing production from domestic deposits, and it is investing in a liquefied natural gas terminal on the Baltic coast.

PGNiG, 85 percent government owned, controls all of Poland's gas imports and another state monopoly, Gas System, handles gas distribution.

entry.headline: General Electric to sell $2.9 bln Swiss Re stake
entry.body:
ZURICH (Reuters) - Swiss Re RUKN.VX said General Electric (GE.N) would divest its stake worth around 3.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.9 billion), selling half to Swiss Re and placing the other half in the market.

Swiss Re had waived a lock-up period on the shares, which General Electric had received as part of the payment for its reinsurance units, which it sold for $7.4 billion to the Swiss reinsurer last year.

"If this transaction completes ... Swiss Re's stand-alone performance could be evaluated by the market, without any uncertainty about ... a large share placement," finance chief George Quinn told journalists in a conference call.

A banking syndicate of Credit Suisse (CSGN.VX), Deutsche Bank (DBKGn.DE), Goldman Sachs (GS.N), Morgan Stanley (MS.N) and UBS (UBSN.VX) separately announced the accelerated bookbuilding for the placement to institutional investors.

The bookbuilding was a precondition for Swiss Re's share re-purchase. Swiss Re's repurchase of the shares from GE was part of a wider share buyback program of up to 6 billion francs, the company said.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-JPMorgan Cazenove expects good year after revenue jump
entry.body:
(Adds interview with CEO, background)

By Louise Heavens

LONDON, March 1 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Cazenove, the UK investment banking joint venture, said on Thursday it expected a good performance in 2007 after posting a 31 percent jump in revenues for 2006.

Earlier the bank said total revenues rose 31 percent in 2006 to 446.7 million pounds ($875 million).

Cazenove [CAZ.UL], the UK firm which set up a joint venture with U.S. investment bank JP Morgan Chase Co (JPM.N), reported operating profit of 87.4 million pounds from its 50 percent share of the venture.

Chief Executive Robert Pickering said activity in the investment banking sector had been boosted by a combination of a wave of liquidity from institutions, hedge funds and private equity, the merger and acquisition ambitions of management teams and a boom in emerging markets.

While global markets were shaken earlier this week after Chinese shares dived on regulatory concerns, the outlook remained positive, he said.

"People's view of risk is very subjective and it's largely a matter of sentiment and as we've seen in the past couple of days that can shift dramatically," said Pickering in a telephone interview.

"2006 conditions were about as good as they get for investment banking, but 2007 looks being a pretty good year as well."

The results come two years on from when Cazenove, one of the most venerable stockbroking names in the City of London's financial arena, gave up more than 180 years of independence to link up with the U.S. investment bank.

Responding to a report in The Business magazine that the joint venture would review the five-year arrangement, Pickering said: "The option is exercisable in 2010. Anything else is speculation. We're anticipating carrying on as we are."

JPMorgan Cazenove acts as corporate broker to more UK clients than any other firm, with 35 of the FTSE 100 listed companies as clients and 80 of the FTSE 250 index of midrange companies.

entry.headline: IBM to keep up 'accelerated' pace of mergers
entry.body:
SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (Reuters) - IBM (IBM.N), the world's largest technology services company, said on Friday it plans this year to keep up the "accelerated" pace of acquisitions set in 2006, when it spent almost $5 billion on 13 companies. The company, in an article on its Web site, did not name potential targets or give details of its acquisition plans, but last year's purchases were focused on software companies, an area in which IBM plans further growth.

International Business Machines Corp. said revenue from the companies it acquired in 2006 rose 50 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, before they were acquired.

"Given IBM's track record, IBM plans to continue the accelerated pace of acquisitions in 2007, depending on valuations," IBM, based in Armonk, New York, said in the article, which was also filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

IBM's acquisitions last year included FileNet Corp., for which it paid $1.6 billion; Internet Security Systems Inc.

($1.4 billion); Micromuse ($900 million) and MRO Software Inc.

($740 million).

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Drug wholesalers fail to block Pfizer deal in UK
entry.body:
(Adds further details on case, Pfizer reaction)

By Ben Hirschler

LONDON, March 2 (Reuters) - Drug wholesalers failed on Friday to block a controversial arrangement making Alliance Boots Plc AB.L the exclusive distributor of medicines from Pfizer Inc (PFE.N), the world's biggest drugmaker.

The high court in London dismissed their application for an injunction to stop the deal coming effect on March 5.

Lawyers for the wholesalers had argued that implementation of the deal -- which gives UniChem, the wholesaling division of Alliance Boots, the right to supply 15,000 pharmacies, hospitals and dispensing doctors in Britain --- should be put on hold pending a full hearing of their challenge.

The British Association of Pharmaceutical Wholesalers (BAPW) said the arrangement would stifle competition and undermine the country's flexible round-the-clock drug ordering and delivery service.

Although Pfizer was entitled to reach the deal it did with UniChem, it should continue to supply other distributors as well, the BAPW said.

Pfizer says it needs the new system to stamp out counterfeiting, following three cases of bogus versions of its top-selling cholesterol fighter Lipitor turning up in the British distribution chain since mid-2005.

Refusing to grant the wholesalers a temporary block on the new arrangement, Justice David Richards said: "My decision is that I refuse your application for an injunction."

The judge said that he would give his reasons on Monday.

U.S.-based Pfizer, whose drugs account for more than 10 percent of those marketed in Britain, said it was delighted by the decision and the scheme would go live as planned on March 5.

"The company is confident that its new distribution arrangement is in full compliance with all applicable EU and UK laws, and that it will secure the supply chain," a spokesman said.

Britain's consumer watchdog, the Office of Fair Trading, has also been looking into the Pfizer deal but was not able to reach a decision on whether to open a formal inquiry before the scheme came into effect.

Critics believe Pfizer's real aim is to fight parallel trade, the legal practice in Europe whereby medicines are imported for resale into places like Britain from countries in southern Europe, where prices are lower.

The success of its new arrangement with Alliance Boots is expected to be monitored closely by other big drugmakers, some of which are considering similar exclusive deals.

entry.headline: Judge rules for Microsoft in Alcatel-Lucent suit
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - A U.S. federal judge dismissed Alcatel-Lucent's ALU.PA(ALU.N) patent claim against Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) over technology that converts speech into text, the two companies said on Friday.

The ruling made late Thursday comes one week after a jury found that the world's largest software maker infringed on audio patents held by Alcatel-Lucent and ordered the company to pay $1.52 billion in damages.

U.S. District Judge Rudi Brewster in San Diego dismissed all of Alcatel-Lucent's claims in a summary judgment, meaning that the jury trial set to begin on March 19 will not take place. Alcatel-Lucent said it plans to appeal the ruling.

"We've made strong arguments supporting our view," said Alcatel-Lucent spokeswoman Joan Campion. "We're comfortable with our chances of success."

Microsoft and Alcatel-Lucent are locked in a number of patent disputes including a suit over the video-coding technology in Microsoft's Xbox 360 video game console.

"This ruling reaffirms our confidence that once there's judicial review of these complex patent cases, these Alcatel-Lucent claims ultimately won't stand up," said Tom Burt, Microsoft's deputy general counsel.

Last week's $1.52 billion award for Alcatel-Lucent was the largest ever in a U.S. patent case. The award is expected to fuel a push by computer and software makers to overhaul the U.S. patent system.

Microsoft has said it plans to ask a judge to knock down the award and will appeal if necessary.

(Additional reporting by Sinead Carew in New York)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-McAfee names ex-EMC exec Dave DeWalt as CEO
entry.body:
(Recasts, adds details, background)

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 (Reuters) - McAfee Inc. MFE.N on Monday named high-tech industry veteran Dave DeWalt to take over as chief executive as the security software maker faces a stock-options accounting scandal and pressure to find new growth.

DeWalt, the former chief executive of Nasdaq-listed Documentum Inc., a maker of document storage software, joined EMC Corp. (EMC.N) in 2003, when the data storage supplier embarked on a major expansion into the software market.

He takes over at McAfee on April 2 and will lead a company preparing to restate several quarters of past financial results and to record between $100 million and $150 million in charges over a 10-year period due to stock options grant problems.

He also will have to fend off Microsoft's (MSFT.O) push into the consumer security software market, which has taken share from both McAfee and market leader Symantec Corp. (SYMC.O), according to a recent report from research firm NPD group.

In May, the No. 2 security software maker fired its president and said George Samenuk would retire as chief executive after an internal investigation found accounting discrepancies in stock option grants.

Also McAfee's former general counsel, Kent Roberts, faces federal charges he illegally back-dated stock options to secure gains for himself and others.

The company is among more than 170 involved in internal or federal regulatory or criminal investigations into manipulations of stock-option grants.

DeWalt replaces interim chief executive and board member Dale Fuller, who took over after Samenuk stepped down, the company said. DeWalt was also named president.

Prior to taking the job at McAfee, DeWalt served as president of EMC's software group. He has worked in the computer industry for two decades, including stints at business software makers including Seque, Quest and and Oracle Corp.

entry.headline: Televisa to start telephone service in July -source
entry.body:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Mexican broadcaster Televisa's Cablevision cable TV unit has pushed back to July plans to offer viewers fixed line telephone service, which would challenge telecom market heavyweight Telmex, an unnamed source at the company said.

Cablevision had previously said its new service, which will give many of its 500,000 clients in Mexico City an alternative to Telmex for the first time, would be launched in February.

Cablevision plans to roll out the service gradually, the source, who was not authorized to be quoted by the press, said on Monday.

"The network won't be up from one day to another," the Televisa source told Reuters. "Cablevision's services always grow by stages."

He did not give a reason for the delay.

Televisa and Telmex, which dominates almost all of Mexico's fixed-line and long-distance telecom industry, are scrambling to launch bundles of telephone, television and Internet service across their lines.

Telmex owns 18 million Mexico's 21 million fixed telephone lines.

The government hopes technology allowing telephone, cable and Internet operators to offer services traditionally provided by rivals over a single connection, will improve competition in Mexico, leading to lower prices and better service.

Telmex also is developing expanded services and has already launched a handful of video channels, although it is still awaiting government permission to offer services comparable to cable or satellite television.

More than half of Mexico's 103 million people lack access to basic phone services.

Upstart telecom Alestra, a partnership between conglomerate Alfa and ATT, offers its services in affluent markets and has about 750,000 fixed lines across the country, including parts of Mexico City.

(With additional reporting by Tomas Sarmiento)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-JP Morgan, B of A among banks Moody's upgrades
entry.body:
(Updates with analyst comment, new bond quote)

By Dena Aubin

NEW YORK, March 5 (Reuters) - Moody's Investors Service has raised its ratings on Bank of America, JP Morgan Chase and Washington Mutual Inc. as part of a sweeping review to include the role government support would play in averting defaults.

The upgrades are among dozens announced by Moody's late on Friday under a new method being applied to more than 1,000 banks in 90 countries over the next five to six weeks.

The new method drew criticism from some analysts, who said Moody's ratings will no longer be a true gauge of credit quality.

JP Morgan Chase Co. (JPM.N) was raised by one notch to "Aa2," the third-highest rating, from "Aa3," while Bank of America Corp. (BAC.N) was raised one notch to "Aa1," the second-highest rating, from "Aa2."

JP Morgan's strong deposit shares, extensive derivatives operations and role as a major government securities clearer make government support virtually certain, Moody's said in a statement.

"Due to the importance of these operations to the U.S. financial system, the potential disruption to the financial markets from any failure or default by such an institution would be massive," Moody's said.

JP Morgan Bank's ratings were raised to a top "Aaa" level from "Aa2."

SPREADS NOT AFFECTED

Bank of America's upgrade was based on its stand-alone financial strength, though the likelihood of government support is also very high because of its No. 1 deposit market position, Moody's said. Its bank's ratings were raised to a top "Aaa" level from "Aa1."

Spreads on JP Morgan's 5.125 percent notes due in 2014 widened by 7 basis points on Monday to 76 basis points over Treasuries, according to MarketAxess.

"Theoretically they should tighten in, but considering what's going on in the markets, it's made it more difficult for that to happen," said Scott MacDonald, director of research at Aladdin Capital in Stamford Connecticut.

"There's also a lot of skepticism about Moody's' decision to do what they did," he said.

Corporate bond spreads have been widening out overall since last week after a plunge in Chinese shares touched off selling in global equities markets worldwide. Corporate bonds opened weaker again on Monday after European credit markets weakened with another sell-off in Asian stock markets.

Some analysts questioned Moody's new ratings approach last month after it upgraded a swathe of European banks, lifting a number to triple-A, including Iceland's three major banks. Those upgrades came just days after rating agency Standard Poor's warned Iceland's banks could face a test as the domestic economy slows and global credit conditions deteriorate.

Moody's upgrades are a result of its decision to more fully incorporate "joint default analysis" into its bank ratings to give them credit for external support from governments, parent companies or other parties.

ANALYSTS PAN CHANGES

Fixed-income research service CreditSights said it is dropping Moody's ratings from its bank research because they are no longer useful as a gauge of credit worth.

"Moody's has discovered when banks run into difficulties, most of them are bailed out, usually by the government," CreditSights analysts Simon Adamson and John Raymond wrote in a report on Sunday. "We don't need a rating to tell us that most banks are too big to fail."

Moody's has "bank financial strength ratings" that gauge stand-alone credit quality without support, but market players will not spend time poring over various ratings to figure out where a bank's bonds should trade, CreditSights said.

"We think we're doing a service by bifurcating the components," Moody's regional credit officer Rosemarie Conforte said in an interview. Though it might take a little more work to read two rating inputs, "we think the transparency is much improved by this methodology because you can see exactly how you get to a credit rating."

Among other changes, Moody's raised Washington Mutual Inc. (WM.N) one notch to "A2," the sixth-highest rating, from "A3."

The Bank of New York was raised by two notches to "Aaa" from "Aa2." The bank is a major government clearer and has a 95 percent probability of government support, Moody's said. The senior ratings at the holding company, the Bank of New York Co. Inc. (BK.N) were unchanged at "Aa3," Moody's said.

Moody's raised Wachovia Corp.'s WB.N Wachovia Bank NA to "Aa1," the second-highest rating, from "Aa2," saying its strong deposit market share gives it a 70 percent chance of government support.

State Street Corp.'s (STT.N) State Street Bank was also raised to "Aa1" from "Aa2" because its dominance in mutual fund servicing gives it a 70 percent probability of government support, Moody's said. (Additional reporting by Jonathan Stempel and Neil Shah in New York and Richard Barley in London)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Venezuela pushes Orinoco takeover with Exxon, Total
entry.body:
(Recasts, adds Exxon, Total comments)

By Brian Ellsworth

CARACAS, March 5 (Reuters) - Venezuela advanced its plan to take over multibillion dollar projects in its Orinoco oil reserve, taking steps on Monday to nationalize the investments with two of the major oil companies involved, Exxon Mobil and Total.

And in a sign of its hard-line negotiating, Energy Minister Rafael Ramirez warned the companies that Venezuela, the No. 4 crude exporter to the United States, would compensate them for seizing a majority stake in their projects in oil -- not cash.

President Hugo Chavez, who is on a nationalization drive this year after a landslide reelection, has decreed that the foreign oil companies running four crude upgrading projects in the Orinoco must hand their operations to the state by May 1.

It has not been clear how the companies would comply with the order, but, on Monday, Exxon (XOM.N), the world's largest company, said it had agreed to hand over its operations in the Orinoco by the OPEC nation's deadline.

And French giant Total (TOTF.PA) said it held talks with Ramirez over its stake in another project in the Orinoco, which is one of the world's largest heavy oil reserves.

Previously companies had said there had been no serious negotiations with the government.

"In Total, we have made a commitment to the minister in the sense that we are going to act in good faith to carry on our work in (the Orinoco) in the future," Total's Chief Executive Officer Christophe de Margerie said at a ceremony in Caracas to sign a deal over compensation for a previously seized field.

"Undoubtedly, for Total and the rest of the partners, the Orinoco represents a high priority," he added.

For years, Chavez, who declares himself an enemy of capitalism, has squeezed foreign oil investments with nationalization moves and taken over some assets in other industries, but the major oil companies' Orinoco investments are the largest he has taken on since coming to power in 1999.

With an estimated value of more than $30 billion, the four Orinoco projects have a production capacity of around 600,000 barrels per day.

Other companies whose investments are targeted for takeover in the reserve include Chevron Corp. (CVX.N), Conoco Phillips (COP.N), Norway's Statoil (STL.OL) and Britain's BP Plc (BP.L).

While they have to cede operations by May 1, they also have several more months to negotiate final terms of any deal over their ownership stakes in the project.

On Monday, Ramirez repeated a threat that if the companies do not reach an agreement over the terms of the projects, the state will take control.

entry.headline: Exxon to hand over Orinoco operation--Venezuela
entry.body:
CARACAS, March 5 (Reuters) - Two oil majors took the first clear steps on Monday to reach an agreement with the leftist government of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez over his plan to nationalize multi-billion dollar projects in the Orinoco belt.

Exxon Mobil, the world's largest company, has agreed to cede its operations in the Orinoco project it runs by May 1 in compliance with a presidential decree, Venezuela's energy minister said.

He later said Venezuela would compensate the oil majors in crude, instead of cash, in the nationalization of their multibillion dollar holdings in projects in the Orinoco reserve.

The chief executive officer of French giant Total (TOTF.PA) also said he held "frank and open" talks on Monday in Caracas with the minister, Rafael Ramirez, over Venezuela's plan to take a majority stake in the Orinoco project it is involved in.

Since a December landslide re-election, Chavez has been on a nationalization drive.

After buying controlling stakes in utility companies in recent weeks, he has now begun to take concrete steps to fulfill his pledge to take over the much larger foreign investments in the Orinoco.

Exxon (XOM.N) was due later on Monday to attend a ceremony marking the company's decision to create a "transition committee" that would work to hand over its operations of the Cerro Negro heavy crude upgrading project in the Orinoco by May 1, Ramirez said.

Companies involved in the Orinoco, which also include Chevron (CVX.N), ConocoPhillips (COP.N), Statoil (STL.OL) and BP (BP.L), have to cede operations by May 1 although they have several more months to negotiate final terms of any deal over their ownership stakes in the project.

Industry sources told Reuters last week Exxon had agreed to hand its operations over by the May 1 deadline.

Ramirez said if companies do not reach an agreement over the terms of the projects in four months, then the state will simply take over their control.

entry.headline: Goldman software analyst Sherlund joins hedge fund
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 5 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) software analyst Rick Sherlund has left the firm to join New York-based Galleon Group, the latest research analyst to leave the sell-side for the more lucrative world of hedge funds.

Sherlund, who could not be reached for comment, was a managing director at Goldman who covered Microsoft (MSFT.O) and other software companies, spokesman Ed Canaday said.

Sherlund, who is 52, in a few weeks will join Galleon Group, a $6.5 billion hedge fund firm to manage a portfolio of technology stocks after 25 years at Goldman.

Galleon officials could not be reached for comment.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-BP to pay $900 mln for Chevron Nerefco stake, assets
entry.body:
(Adds new details throughout)

NEW YORK, March 5 (Reuters) - British oil giant BP Plc (BP.L) said on Monday it agreed to buy Chevron Corp.'s (CVX.N) Dutch manufacturing business for around $900 million, including the remaining 31 percent of the 400,000 barrel a day Nerefco refinery that BP does not already own.

BP said in a statement it would acquire U.S. oil company Chevron's stake in Netherlands Refining Co (Nerefco) as well as its 31 percent stake in the jointly-owned wind farm located at the refinery.

It is also buying Chevron's 22.8 percent interest in the nearby TEAM crude oil terminal and storage facility and a number of associated pipelines.

BP already owns 69 percent of Nerefco and the wind farm, but does not own any stakes in the remaining assets, Chevron said in a separate statement.

Chevron said it expects the deal to close in the first quarter. (Additional reporting by Dan Lalor in London)

entry.headline: Energy industry inflation boosts oil - Goldman
entry.body:
LONDON, March 5 (Reuters) - Cost inflation in the energy industry that has forced delays to new oil projects will help support forward oil prices despite a sell-off in global equity markets, Goldman Sachs (GS.N) said on Monday.

"While equity markets plunged last week with SP 500 selling off 3.5 percent on Tuesday, the energy markets were remarkably unaffected," the U.S. investment bank said in its latest weekly energy note.

The equity market slide continued on Monday, with European shares, for example, down nearly two percent on Monday after sharp falls in Asian markets.

Oil prices for nearby delivery have fallen back in response to the equity market downturn. U.S. crude prices were down more than $1 at $60.63 a barrel on Tuesday.

Despite this retreat, nearby oil prices are still near their highest in two months and above a 20 month low in mid-January of just under $50 a barrel.

Long-dated oil prices, in particular, have proved especially resilient.

"This resilience has been rooted in the strong support from the ongoing cost inflation in the energy industy, which continues to raise the cost of bringing energy on-stream and sustains higher oil prices," it said.

Goldman said longer-dated prices for U.S. crude oil continued to climb above $67 a barrel last week despite the turmoil in world stock markets.

But despite this resilience, forward oil prices are, in fact, not high enough to encourage sufficient investment in the energy sector to bring new production onstream, the bank said.

A levelling off in forward prices, plus the cost inflation has put pressure on the balance sheets of oil companies making it tough for firms to foot the bill for new production projects.

"Cost overruns and new field start-up delays continue to hit the news," Goldman said. "As well as the perception that expanding capacity and reserves via upstream MA, as opposed to field investments, is increasingly the most appealing option for oil companies."

Goldman said higher oil prices were needed to accommodate these rising costs and support production expansion that has so far been lacklustre.

"Expensive alternative energy sources and technologies such as fuel ethanol, oil sands...will increasingly be needed to relieve demand pressure on oil supply, lending further support to long-dated oil prices."

entry.headline: JP Morgan's Dimon to plead case on moves - WSJ
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 5 (Reuters) - After 2- years of slashing costs and plowing money into key businesses, J.P. Morgan Chase Co.'s (JPM.N) top executive, James Dimon, must convince investors at a meeting on Tuesday that those efforts can pump up revenue growth and profitability in everything from retail branches to bond trading, according to a report in The Wall Street Jounral.

Investors are also likely to question him on the possibility of acquisitions, an issue Dimon addressed at the end of January, the Journal reported.

Dimon is well aware of the longstanding criticism that the bank hasn't shown consistent internal growth. The pressure to do so comes amid tougher conditions this year in the banking industry, where profits are likely to be hurt by weakening credit quality, fierce competition for deposits and loans and a difficult interest-rate environment, the Journal said.

Dimon and the top bosses of the bank's key businesses on Tuesday are expected to provide some fresh details about how they plan to fatten the bank's bottom line, the Journal said. They might fine-tune some targets for the bank's operations but aren't expected to disclose any big new strategies for the bank, the Journal reported.

It will be J.P. Morgan's first daylong meeting with investors since Dimon, who was named chief executive officer of J.P. Morgan last year, also became chairman after the recent retirement of William Harrison.

entry.headline: Microsoft to blast Google over copyright policy
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) is set to launch a blistering attack on rival Google Inc. (GOOG.O) on Tuesday for what the software giant argues is the Web search leader's "cavalier" approach to copyright protection.

In prepared remarks to be delivered to the Association of American Publishers, Microsoft Associate General Counsel Thomas Rubin argues that Google's move into new media markets has come at the expense of publishers of books, videos and software.

The Microsoft attorney's comments echo arguments at the heart of a 16-month-old copyright lawsuit against Google brought by five major book publishers and organized by the Association of American Publishers, an industry trade group.

"Companies that create no content of their own, and make money solely on the backs of other people's content, are raking in billions through advertising revenue and IPOs," says Rubin, who oversees copyright and trade secret law at Microsoft.

"Google takes the position that everything may be freely copied unless the copyright owner notifies Google and tells it to stop," said Rubin, noting that Microsoft takes the position of seeking the copyright owner's consent before they copy.

Competition is heating up this year between Google, the world's dominant provider of Web search services, and software giant Microsoft, which recently entered the Web search market.

At the same time, Google has recently expanded into the business software market with a set of Web-based subscription services it sees as a major revenue generator which could chip away at Microsoft's 15-year dominance of computer software.

Rubin invokes criticism that Google has faced since its acquisition late last year of YouTube, which has come under fire from several major media companies for allowing widespread copyright infringement of professionally produced video.

"In essence, Google is saying to you and to other copyright owners: 'Trust us - you're protected. We'll keep the digital copies secure, we'll only show snippets, we won't harm you, we'll promote you,'" Rubin argues in his speech.

"But Google's track record of protecting copyrights in other parts of its business is weak at best," he said.

David Drummond, Google's senior vice president for corporate development and its chief legal officer, said in response that Google works with more than 10,000 publishing partners to make books searchable online and has recently added the BBC and NBA basketball league as YouTube video partners.

"We do this by complying with international copyright laws, and the result has been more exposure and in many cases more revenue for authors, publishers and producers of content."

Rubin cites anecdotal media reports that a handful of Google sales people were caught encouraging advertisers to capitalize on the demand for pirated software on the Web.

Rubin sides with publishers in criticizing Google's ambitious plan to scan millions of published works in the world's great libraries and make them available to consumers via its Google Book Search system. He said by scanning copies of published works without first seeking copyright holders' permission, Google opens the door to massive infringement.

The attorney also says Google's defense of 'fair use' is overly broad. "Concocting a novel "fair use" theory, Google bestowed upon itself the unilateral right to make entire copies of copyrighted books," Rubin argues.

Drummond replied: "The goal of search engines, and of products like Google Book Search and YouTube, is to help users find information from content producers of every size."

The publishers' lawsuit against Google, filed in October 2005 in the U.S. District for the Southern District of New York, remains in the discovery process with no trial date set.

Microsoft's move bears parallels to an attack five years ago by the Redmond, Washington-based company on so-called "open source" software, which has emerged over the past decade as the biggest alternative to Microsoft's Windows software franchise.

Microsoft argued then that open source software jeopardized property rights and threatened to undermine the software industry as it argued in favor of "shared source" software that reinforced intellectual property rights.

(Additional reporting by Eric Auchard in San Francisco)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-JPMorgan chairman feels no pressure for dealmaking
entry.body:
(Recasts, adds details)

NEW YORK, March 6 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM.N) Chairman Jamie Dimon said on Tuesday that regional bank consolidation in the United States presents such a big opportunity for an acquisition that he feels no pressure to rush into any deal.

Dimon, who runs the third-largest U.S. bank, said his executive team is "acquisition capable" and no longer preoccupied with digesting past acquisitions.

Dimon made his remarks at JPMorgan's investor day in Manhattan.

Some Wall Street analysts expect JPMorgan to buy a large regional bank to expand the company's retail branch footprint in the U.S. South or West, for example.

Dimon didn't say anything to discourage that thinking. As he has said previously, Dimon expects further consolidation among regional banks.

"The opportunity looks so large," Dimon said, that he didn't feel any pressure "to do anything."

For now, Dimon and his team say they are happy to improve productivity and efficiency while generating internal growth in businesses that include investment banking, mortgage lending, credit cards and asset management. He said JPMorgan's franchise in these areas would be hard to duplicate today.

((Reporting by Tim McLaughlin, editing by Gary Hill, Reuters messaging: tim.mclaughlin.reuters.com@reuters.net; +1 646 223 6033)) Keywords: JPMORGAN ACQUISITIONS

entry.headline: JPMorgan shed 4 mln sq ft net real estate in 2006
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 6 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase Co. (JPM.N) said on Tuesday it shrank its corporate footprint by 4 million square feet last year as the third-largest U.S. bank sold real estate and consolidated office space.

JPMorgan said its corporate real estate fell to 67.4 million square feet from 71.4 million square feet at the end of 2005, JPMorgan executive Frank Bisignano said at a conference for investors.

He said the net reduction was the equivalent of getting rid of JPMorgan's Manhattan tower at 270 Park Avenue four times over. The tower remains a crown jewel among JPMorgan's real estate holdings, but the company has moved thousands of workers out of Manhattan to other sites in New Jersey and Brooklyn, for example, Bisignano said.

"This is a work in progress forever," he said.

In mid-Manhattan, JPMorgan owns 3.3 million square feet of office space, down from 4.6 million in 2005, Bisignano said.

Last year, JPMorgan shed 7 million square feet of space, but added back 3 million square feet, investing in new retail branches and data centers while acquiring square footage in its acquisition of branches from the Bank of New York.

LONDON/NEW YORK, March 6 (Reuters) - The following financial service industry appointments and moves were announced on Tuesday. To inform us of other job changes, please e-mail moves@reuters.com.

GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP INC. (GS.N)

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said Stephen Scherr, chief operating officer of the firm's investment banking division for the past two years, will take charge of its Americas financing group, according to an internal memo distributed Tuesday.

Scherr succeeds Rob Pace, who will become a senior adviser to top clients and work on strategy and marketing for the banking division.

The memo also said Gregg Lemkau, the firm's co-head of health-care investment banking, will become chief operating officer for the investment banking division, replacing Scherr.

The unit of international law firm Bryan Cave LLP added five people to its Bangkok office and one person to its office in Malaysia.

Malika Bhumivarn will lead the group in Bangkok, serving as regional director, Customs Trade. He will advise clients on customs, trade and investment matters.

Dato' Hj. Mohammed Adnan bin Ariffin will join the company in Malaysia as advisor, Malaysian Customs Affairs. He previously served in the Royal Malaysian Customs Department for more than 33 years.

Kittipong Jangkamolkulchai joins the company as regional manager. He has advised clients on various business transactions associated with tax liability exposures and has provided customs audit services.

Weerasak Chunharungroj is a certified customs specialist and will be assistant manager, Thai Customs Affairs.

Saowakon Sritongpanich, also an assistant manager, is a tax incentive specialist and has presented cases before the Thai Board of Investment and the Industrial Estates Authority of Thailand.

Somruekarn Wongsaroj joins the company as a senior analyst.

DEUTSCHE BANK (DBKGn.DE)

Deutsche Bank announced that Charles Y. Lee will join its Global Banking Division as a director in the Global Commercial Real Estate group, specializing in CMBS and CDO execution.

Based in New York, he will report to Lainie Kaye, a managing director and head of CMBS securitization. He will also have reporting responsibilities to Emile Van-Den-Bol, a managing director and global head of CRE CDOs.

Lee joins Deutsche Bank after 10 years with JPMorgan, where he was most recently a vice president on the commercial real estate securitization team.

PATTON BOGGS LLP

Law firm Patton Boggs LLP added Michael A. Smith and Timothy J. Pfister as partners in its New York office.

Pfister will continue to focus on international corporate transactions and Smith will concentrate on cross-border corporate finance and MA matters.

BNP PARIBAS (BNPP.PA)

The French bank appointed Justin Bisgood to the Financial Institutions Group (FIG).

Based in London, he will report directly to Jeremy Humphreys-Davies, head of FIG UK, Ireland and Scandinavia.

Bisgood will cover the major British banking groups, with a focus on developing the company's key product lines within the sector.

STATE STREET CORPORATION (STT.N)

State Street Corp. appointed Michael Walsh to head of State Street's investment servicing business in Britain, the Middle East and Africa (UKMEA).

He will report to Peter O'Neill, executive vice president and head of State Street's investment servicing and investment research and trading businesses for UKMEA.

Walsh was responsible for managing State Street's investment servicing business in Scotland since October 2005. He joined the company in 2004 as head of WM Performance Services, the company's European performance measurement division.

The Swiss bank has hired Russell Chambers from rival UBS (UBSN.VX) to be chief executive of its UK arm.

Chambers will be based in London and start in early June. He will report to Leonhard Fischer, CEO of the bank's Europe, Middle East and Africa division.

Chambers was a managing director in UBS's investment banking division and before that was head of British investment banking at Investec. He spent 13 years at Merrill Lynch.

To read more, please double click on [nL06479827]

AFFILIATED MANAGERS GROUP, INC. (AMG.N)

The asset management holding company, announced the appointment of Jay Horgen as executive vice president focusing on investments in new AMG affiliates.

Most recently, Horgen founded a private equity firm, Eastside Partners, where he served as a managing director. From 1993 to 2005, he was an investment banker serving as a managing director in the Financial Institutions Group at Merrill Lynch MER.N. He also worked as a banker in the Financial Institutions Group at Goldman, Sachs Co. (GS.N)

BARCLAYS WEALTH

Barclays Wealth, part of Barclays Group (BARC.L), appointed Torben Nielsen as managing director, head of Balance Sheet.

He will report to Chief Investment Officer Kevin Lecocq and will oversee the development of products and services that utilize the availability of a large balance sheet.

Nielsen will also work with the Treasury departments of Barclays Plc and Barclays Capital and assume responsibility for the development of a new risk management framework.

BMO CAPITAL MARKETS

BMO Capital Markets, the investment and corporate banking arm of BMO Financial Group (BMO.TO), hired a four-person team based in London to focus on smaller quoted companies on the Official List and the Alternative Investment Market (AIM).

BMO Capital Markets also applied for membership on the London Stock Exchange and is awaiting final approval.

The team will look at companies in the resources, energy and technology sectors that are listed or have intentions of listing on the London Stock Exchange or AIM. The new group will be headed by Jamie Strauss, who joins BMO Capital Markets as managing director of UK Equity Products.

He will be responsible for developing and managing an AIM/LSE business as well as continuing as a specialist mining salesman. Prior to joining BMO, Strauss was a founding partner of Hargreave Hale, where he spent five years building an institutional mining specialist sales and research team.

Strauss also served in the sales group of Societe Generale (SOGN.PA), where he worked on British and European equities with a strong interest in the mining world.

Kelly Carter joins the team as vice president, with responsibility for sales and trading coverage. Prior to joining the team at Hargreave Hale, Carter was a sales-trader at Societe Generale Strauss Turnbull in London.

Sacha Borthwick joins the team as a director and mining analyst, after 10 years in mining research at Hargreave Hale and Societe Generale.

Ed Sterck will work with Borthwick as an associate. Sterck has a BSc (Hons) from the Royal School of Mines, Imperial College in London. Prior to working in mining research, Sterck was a financial futures trader.

DELOITTE FINANCIAL ADVISORY SERVICES LLP

Deloitte Financial Advisory Services LLP (Deloitte FAS), a subsidiary of Deloitte Touche USA LLP, named David Gilles a director in its Forensic Dispute Services, Anti-Money Laundering practice.

Based in Washington, D.C., he will help clients developeffective anti-money laundering programs including with regard to AML regulation, customer acquisition due diligence, account-based monitoring and suspicious activity reporting.

ARLINGTON SECURITIES

Investment management and property services company Arlington Securities appointed Nicola Willis as assistant fund manager and Helen Smith as retail asset manager.

Willis joins the company from Jones Lang LaSalle, where she worked with the property asset management and valuation teams, qualifying as a surveyor in 2006.

Smith's responsibilities as retail asset manager will cover in town shopping centers and high street retail. Prior to joining Arlington, Helen was Property Manager for Bluewater at Lend Lease.

THE BANK OF NEW YORK (BK.N)

The Bank of New York, a provider of securities servicing, has added to its securities servicing division with the appointment of five new recruits: Elizabeth Fitzgibbons, Elin Toerre, Neil Atkinson, Maura O'Sullivan and David Prestwich.

Palm Inc., a provider of mobile computing solutions, has appointed Mark Doorbar as senior director of marketing for Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA). Doorbar began his career at Cadbury Schweppes CBRY.L, before joining Pepsi Cola International and more recently at food producer RHM RHM.L.

Johan Roos has been named head of group finance, with effect from May 1. Roos will succeed Per-Arne Blomquist who became chief financial officer of the North European financial group in October last year. Roos is currently finance director for Hewlett-Packard (HPQ.N) in Sweden, and has previously worked as audit director and authorised public accountant at Ohrlings PricewaterhouseCoopers. entry.headline: SasolChevron stands by Qatar GTL plans, costs up
entry.body:
DOHA, March 6 (Reuters) - SasolChevron remains interested in projects to boost capacity at a gas-to-liquids (GTL) plant in Qatar and to build another, even though costs are rising as the company awaits the government's go-ahead for new gas schemes.

"It's still the plan," said Patrick Butcher, Qatar country manager for SasolChevron, a joint venture between South Africa's Sasol (SOLJ.J) and U.S. company Chevron Corp. (CVX.N).

"The costs are going up. We can't help that," he said on the sidelines of an energy conference.

Butcher said the costs for SasolChevron to boost capacity at the Oryx GTL plant, from 34,000 barrels per day to around 100,000 bpd by 2009, would now be much higher than the initial estimate of around $1.5 billion.

He declined to give a new estimate.

GTL plants produce clean-burning fuels such as diesel, demand for which is rising as governments tighten emissions regulations.

SasolChevron also still has plans to build a second, larger GTL plant with capacity of 130,000 bpd. That plant had an initial price tag of $4.5 billion.

The schemes are two out of four GTL plants that are on hold after Qatar declared a moratorium on new projects from its massive North Field gas reservoir in 2005.

Qatar does not expect to complete a study of the North Field, the world's largest reservoir of pure gas not associated with oil, until 2009. Only then will it decide whether to give the go-ahead for any more liquefied natural gas (LNG) or GTL projects.

MORATORIUM

While the projects remain on the drawing board, potential costs have spiralled due to rapid inflation in the global oil and gas industry as the sector strains to bring online new projects to meet rapidly rising energy demand.

In February, rising costs forced ExxonMobil (XOM.N) to drop its plans -- which were not subject to the moratorium -- to build the world's largest GTL plant in Qatar.

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSa.L) is forging ahead with its Qatar Pearl GTL plant, despite costs rocketing to as much as $18 billion. The initial cost of the project was $5 billion in 2003.

"Our projects depend on the results of the moratorium," said Butcher. "But it's a great opportunity for us here."

After Exxon dropped its project, some questioned the viability of GTL technology. Butcher said that he had confidence in it and the technology had not achieved industry-wide recognition simply because so few plants exist.

SasolChevron would build more GTL plants elsewhere, even if the Qatar plants were scrubbed, he said. It has another scheme under way for a 34,000 bpd plant in Nigeria. Algeria, Australia and Russia were other potential targets for GTL plants, he said.

"One country will be advantaged by our growing experience in GTL," he said. "I hope it is here."

The $1 billion Oryx plant is currently starting up. It will take 9-12 months to reach full production, the plant's technical manager Lowrens Jacobs said in a presentation on Tuesday at the same energy event. The plant expects to make its first shipment of diesel by the end of the month.

Sasol has a 49 percent stake in the Oryx plant, while state-owned Qatar Petroleum owns the remaining 51 percent.

entry.headline: JPMorgan passes Goldman Sachs in hedge fund list
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 5 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase & Co.'s (JPM.N) hedge funds have overtaken Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s (GS.N), helped by a 74 percent surge in assets under management, Absolute Return magazine said on Monday in its semi-annual survey of U.S. hedge funds.

JPMorgan Asset Management's hedge funds, including Highbridge Capital Management, majority owned by the bank since 2004, had $34 billion under management as of Jan. 1, according to the magazine.

Goldman Sachs, which had led the two previous rankings in 2006, saw its hedge fund assets rise 48 percent from a year ago to $32.53.

Bridgewater Associates, a fund management firm based in Westport, Connecticut, was in third place with $30.20 with a 47 percent increase and D.E. Shaw group was in fourth with $26.20 billion, up 40 percent from a year ago.

Overall, the biggest U.S. hedge funds have combined assets of $1.2 trillion, according to the survey, with the top 20 firms controlling an ever-increasing piece of the pie.

entry.headline: Goldman plans fund for mid-market deals: sources
entry.body:
LONDON (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) plans to invest up to $1 billion of its own money as part of its first dedicated initiative to buy mid-size companies, people familiar with the situation said on Tuesday.

The U.S.-based bank is initially seeking roughly 10 deals requiring an equity investment of between $50 million and $100 million each, the sources said, but that could expand if there are more opportunities available.

The initiative, known as Goldman Sachs Direct Partners, will use a pool of the bank's money separate from a new private equity fund it is raising, which other sources have put at more than $15 billion.

The middle-market fund, which will target companies around the world, also plans to find partners for the deals, the sources said.

Goldman Sachs declined to comment.

The fund will look across a range of sectors for opportunities, including renewable energy, sources said, an area where the bank already has invested more than $1.5 billion.

Goldman Sachs also has been widening the scope of its merger advisory business to include middle-market deals.

entry.headline: Microsoft to blast Google over copyright policy
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) is set to launch a blistering attack on rival Google Inc. (GOOG.O) on Tuesday for what the software giant argues is the Web search leader's "cavalier" approach to copyright protection.

In prepared remarks to be delivered to the Association of American Publishers, Microsoft Associate General Counsel Thomas Rubin argues that Google's move into new media markets has come at the expense of publishers of books, videos and software.

The Microsoft attorney's comments echo arguments at the heart of a 16-month-old copyright lawsuit against Google brought by five major book publishers and organized by the Association of American Publishers, an industry trade group.

"Companies that create no content of their own, and make money solely on the backs of other people's content, are raking in billions through advertising revenue and IPOs," says Rubin, who oversees copyright and trade secret law at Microsoft.

"Google takes the position that everything may be freely copied unless the copyright owner notifies Google and tells it to stop," said Rubin, noting that Microsoft takes the position of seeking the copyright owner's consent before they copy.

Competition is heating up this year between Google, the world's dominant provider of Web search services, and software giant Microsoft, which recently entered the Web search market.

At the same time, Google has recently expanded into the business software market with a set of Web-based subscription services it sees as a major revenue generator which could chip away at Microsoft's 15-year dominance of computer software.

Rubin invokes criticism that Google has faced since its acquisition late last year of YouTube, which has come under fire from several major media companies for allowing widespread copyright infringement of professionally produced video.

"In essence, Google is saying to you and to other copyright owners: 'Trust us - you're protected. We'll keep the digital copies secure, we'll only show snippets, we won't harm you, we'll promote you,'" Rubin argues in his speech.

"But Google's track record of protecting copyrights in other parts of its business is weak at best," he said.

David Drummond, Google's senior vice president for corporate development and its chief legal officer, said in response that Google works with more than 10,000 publishing partners to make books searchable online and has recently added the BBC and NBA basketball league as YouTube video partners.

"We do this by complying with international copyright laws, and the result has been more exposure and in many cases more revenue for authors, publishers and producers of content."

Rubin cites anecdotal media reports that a handful of Google sales people were caught encouraging advertisers to capitalize on the demand for pirated software on the Web.

Rubin sides with publishers in criticizing Google's ambitious plan to scan millions of published works in the world's great libraries and make them available to consumers via its Google Book Search system. He said by scanning copies of published works without first seeking copyright holders' permission, Google opens the door to massive infringement.

The attorney also says Google's defense of 'fair use' is overly broad. "Concocting a novel "fair use" theory, Google bestowed upon itself the unilateral right to make entire copies of copyrighted books," Rubin argues.

Drummond replied: "The goal of search engines, and of products like Google Book Search and YouTube, is to help users find information from content producers of every size."

The publishers' lawsuit against Google, filed in October 2005 in the U.S. District for the Southern District of New York, remains in the discovery process with no trial date set.

Microsoft's move bears parallels to an attack five years ago by the Redmond, Washington-based company on so-called "open source" software, which has emerged over the past decade as the biggest alternative to Microsoft's Windows software franchise.

Microsoft argued then that open source software jeopardized property rights and threatened to undermine the software industry as it argued in favor of "shared source" software that reinforced intellectual property rights.

(Additional reporting by Eric Auchard in San Francisco)

entry.headline: Televisa to start telephone service in July -source
entry.body:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Mexican broadcaster Televisa's Cablevision cable TV unit has pushed back to July plans to offer viewers fixed line telephone service, which would challenge telecom market heavyweight Telmex, an unnamed source at the company said.

Cablevision had previously said its new service, which will give many of its 500,000 clients in Mexico City an alternative to Telmex for the first time, would be launched in February.

Cablevision plans to roll out the service gradually, the source, who was not authorized to be quoted by the press, said on Monday.

"The network won't be up from one day to another," the Televisa source told Reuters. "Cablevision's services always grow by stages."

He did not give a reason for the delay.

Televisa and Telmex, which dominates almost all of Mexico's fixed-line and long-distance telecom industry, are scrambling to launch bundles of telephone, television and Internet service across their lines.

Telmex owns 18 million Mexico's 21 million fixed telephone lines.

The government hopes technology allowing telephone, cable and Internet operators to offer services traditionally provided by rivals over a single connection, will improve competition in Mexico, leading to lower prices and better service.

Telmex also is developing expanded services and has already launched a handful of video channels, although it is still awaiting government permission to offer services comparable to cable or satellite television.

More than half of Mexico's 103 million people lack access to basic phone services.

Upstart telecom Alestra, a partnership between conglomerate Alfa and ATT, offers its services in affluent markets and has about 750,000 fixed lines across the country, including parts of Mexico City.

(With additional reporting by Tomas Sarmiento)

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-ExxonMobil to shut Singapore refinery in June-July
entry.body:
(Adds regional perspective, market impact)

By Yaw Yan Chong

SINGAPORE, March 6 (Reuters) - Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) will shut the larger of its two refining facilities in Singapore for a 45-day regular maintenance from mid-June, refining sources said on Tuesday.

The 309,000 barrels per day (bpd) plant on mainland Singapore will be shut until second-half July, with its crude distillation units (CDUs) as well as other secondary facilities taken down in stages, the sources added.

With this shutdown, the total regional capacity lost during June-July is about 8 percent less than in the year-ago period, which could pressure refining margins that turned positive in January after being in the red for about three months amid a weak middle distillates market, traders said.

"This is Exxon Mobil's second big one in two years. After this, there shouldn't be any major ones, other than routine jobs on secondary units, for a while," a refining source said.

When contacted, a spokesman for the U.S. oil major declined comment.

Last March, the Exxon Mobil shut down its other plant, the 296,000-bpd facility on Jurong Island off the west coast.

It is not known if Singapore's two other refineries -- Shell's 458,000-bpd complex and Singapore Refining Co.'s 285,000-bpd plant -- will be taken down this year as both underwent major turnarounds last year.

IMPACT

Exxon Mobil's turnaround comes at the end of the second-quarter Asian maintenance season, which sees several regional refineries, including in South Korea, Japan and the Middle East, undergoing routine maintenance during the June-July period.

The total regional capacity that will be lost during June-July is about 938,000 bpd with the Exxon Mobil shutdown, compared to about 1.02 million bpd in the same period last year. In addition, Saudi Aramco will shut its 550,000-bpd Ras Tanura refinery from late-April till June. The capacity loss during the April-June turnaround season in the Asia-Pacific region this year, excluding the Exxon Mobil shutdown, will be 1.076 million bpd.

This is 5 percent less than for the same period in 2006, when many regional plants were forced to shut for maintenance after being optimised to meet increased demand a year earlier in the wake of the devastating hurricanes that hit the U.S. Gulf Coast.

"There will be some impact on the market but it won't be a big, rapid change in demand-supply patterns," a Singapore-based Western fuel oil trader said. "For example, I would expect differentials to show a steady state, subject to other short-term market forces."

Simple margins for Asia were at $2.17 a barrel on Tuesday, Reuters data show, down from a recent peak of $3.30 on Jan. 12, and rebounding from a brief dip into the red about a week ago. Differentials for the benchmark 0.5 percent sulphur gas oil grade have stayed below a premium of 50 cents a barrel to Singapore spot quotes since last July, mostly in discount, due to poor demand following a warmer-than-usual winter in North Asia.

The Exxon Mobil shutdown could also increase fuel oil volumes, supporting the market at a time when supplies are seasonally low due to the peak summer demand season in the Middle East, which typically sees exports from that region reduced by half, traders said.
