entry.headline: Microsoft Web search exec leaving company: source
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - The Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) executive in charge of closing the gap on Web search leader Google Inc (GOOG.O) is leaving the company, a source familiar with the situation said on Wednesday.

Chris Payne, corporate vice president of Windows Live search, is leaving Microsoft to start his own company in Seattle, said the source, who asked not to be identified. A Microsoft spokesman declined to comment.

Payne's departure takes place at a time when Microsoft continues to struggle against Google in Internet search even though the company has tried to overhaul its search site with a new look and features.

Google captured 47.5 percent of the online search market share in January with 3.3 billion queries compared to 10.6 percent for Microsoft with 733 million queries, according to data from research firm comScore Networks Inc.

Microsoft's share in January was a slight improvement from 10.5 percent in December, but a decline from 11 percent in November.

Payne, who rejoined Microsoft in 2001 after a three-year stint at Amazon.com (AMZN.O), played a key role in persuading the company to develop its own search engine instead of relying on Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O)

Prior to Amazon, Payne spent 8 years at Microsoft.

Microsoft's late start in search put the company at a disadvantage to Google and Yahoo. Those companies made billions selling advertising tied to search results while Microsoft scrambled to build a business of its own.

Payne would become the second executive from Microsoft's Internet arm in the last week planning to leave the company . Blake Irving, a Microsoft vice president who oversees the company's AdCenter system that sells ads next to search results, plans to retire, Microsoft said.

entry.headline: Microsoft's Gates warns on U.S. competitiveness
entry.body:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates said on Wednesday he feels "deep anxiety" about the state of U.S. competitiveness and called for education, immigration and research funding reforms.

"When I reflect on the state of American competitiveness today, my immediate feeling is not only one of pride, but also of deep anxiety. Too often we as a society are sacrificing the long-term good of our country in the interest of short-term gain," Gates told a Senate committee.

He said government needs to invest more money in education and training, especially in high school math and science, as well as in job training programs.

"Our high schools are no longer a path to opportunity and success, but a barrier to both," Gates told the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, chaired by Massachusetts Democratic Sen. Edward Kennedy.

"While most students enter high school wanting to succeed, too many end up bored, unchallenged and disengaged from the high school curriculum -- 'digital natives' caught up in an industrial-age learning model," he said.

Gates urged higher state math curriculum standards, more support for teachers, and reauthorization of the federal "No Child Left Behind" legislation, which uses testing to measure student progress and holds schools accountable for standards.

He recommended that the nation set a goal of doubling the number of science, technology and math graduates by 2015, and to recruit 10,000 new science and math teachers annually.

Gates urged Congress to find ways to keep foreign students here and to expedite the path to permanent resident status for highly skilled workers to help retain talent, instead of forcing employers to send development work offshore.

He said it "makes no sense" that foreign students who apply for a U.S. student visa must prove that they do not intend to remain in the country once they receive their degree.

"If we are going to invest in educating foreign students ... why drive them away just when this investment starts to pay off for the American economy?" he said.

"I see the negative effects of these policies every day at Microsoft," Gates said, referring to the giant software company he founded. Scientists and engineers from India and China routinely wait more than five years to obtain a U.S. green card, he said.

America's ability to remain a technological powerhouse will depend in large part on federal government investment in basic research, Gates said. He urged increased funding for basic science research and permanent extension of the RD tax credit, which expires at the end of 2007.

"As federal research priorities expand into new areas, we should seek to increase funding for basic research by 10 percent annually over the next seven years," he said.

He said Congress should consider other "innovative" ideas, such as new research grants for outstanding early-career researchers, as well as ensuring research projects are communicated to the private sector so companies can collaborate more effectively with recipients of public research funds.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Exxon Mobil not planning new Venezuela investments
entry.body:
(Adds details)

NEW YORK, March 7 (Reuters) - Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) is not planning any new investment in Venezuela, Chief Executive Rex Tillerson said on Wednesday.

Venezuela is attempting to strip majority control of multibillion-dollar heavy oil projects in the country's Orinoco region from some of the world's biggest oil companies.

"Given the conditions down there at this time and the uncertainty around how our current holdings are going to be dealt with, we are not contemplating any new investment in Venezuela," Tillerson said, speaking at a meeting with analysts in New York.

Exxon Mobil said on Monday it was in talks with the Venezuelan government over President Hugo Chavez's plan for state oil company PDVSA to take at least a 60 percent stake in the multibillion-dollar Cerro Negro heavy oil project. Exxon Mobin said it is negotiating on issues including value, compensation and contract sanctity.

Exxon Mobil is a 41.7 percent partner in Cerro Negro and operates the project through a subsidiary. BP Plc (BP.L) is a 16.6 percent investor in the project, and PDVSA owns the rest.

Exxon Mobil has already agreed to transfer operatorship to PDVSA by May 1.

Tillerson said the company has already pulled some workers out of Venezuela, calling it a "fairly normal transition."

In Russia, Exxon's huge Sakhalin-1 project is being closely watched after Gazprom (GAZP.MM) took the majority stake in Sakhalin-2, the Sakhalin Island project led by Royal Dutch Shell Plc (RDSa.L). Many analysts believe the takeover amounts to a renationalization.

Tillerson said he has no anxiety about an upcoming environmental inspection of the project.

He also said the company looks forward to "finding something else to do in Russia."

He said Exxon Mobil has "no changes planned on an imminent basis" on the leverage of the company.

(Updates to early afternoon)

NEW YORK, March 7 (Reuters) - U.S. stocks were flat on Wednesday as concerns about economic growth and a diminished appetite for risk kept investors cautious, but higher crude oil prices lifted shares of energy companies such as Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N)

Investors scoured the market for beaten-down shares after the past week's sell-off. The February jobs report from the Labor Department, due on Friday, may shed light on the economy's health.

There were also lingering concerns about rising loan defaults in the mortgage market for borrowers with sketchy credit profiles, with shares of Accredited Home Lenders Holding Co. LEND.O down 4.7 percent on the Nasdaq.

Shares of Boeing Co. (BA.N) were the Dow's biggest advancer, up 1.4 percent, at $89.01 on the New York Stock Exchange, but their climb was countered by a 1.5 percent drop in shares of No. 4 U.S. credit card issuer American Express Co. (AXP.N), to $55.53.

Exxon Mobil shares rose 1.5 percent to $72.07 on the NYSE as crude for April delivery jumped 1.7 percent, or $1.02, to $61.70 after a government report showed a surprise drawdown in U.S. crude supplies.

entry.headline: Exxon plans 25 new projects in next three years
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N) plans to start 25 new global projects in the next three years, adding about 1 million barrels of oil equivalent per day to its base volumes when they reach their peak, the world's largest publicly traded oil company said on Wednesday.

The company said its current project inventory is expected to produce 24 billion oil-equivalent barrels over the life of the projects.

Exxon Mobil Senior Vice President Stuart McGill said the company plans to start production at seven new projects in 2007 that will add about 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to the company's base volumes.

The projects the company plans to bring on line this year include four projects in Europe, two projects in Angola, and a liquefied natural gas (LNG) unit at its RasGas project in Qatar.

It plans to startup 18 additional projects over the course of 2008 and 2009, including the company's Thunder Horse joint venture with BP Plc (BP.L), several projects in Qatar and West Africa, and three LNG terminals.

The company also said it has more than 30 other major projects it plans to start up in 2010 or later.

Rex Tillerson, chairman and chief executive, also said he expects the company's capital spending to be around $20 billion a year through 2011.

"I expect very active levels of investment beyond the end of the decade," Tillerson, speaking at the company's analyst meeting in New York.

Shares of the Irving, Texas-based company were up 30 cents at $71.30 in late morning trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

(Additional reporting by Euan Rocha and Michele Gershberg)

CHICAGO (Reuters) - The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved expanded use of Pfizer Inc. (PFE.N)'s blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor to five new categories, the company said on Wednesday.

Pfizer, the world's biggest drugmaker, said the FDA approved the drug for new uses including treating nonfatal heart attacks, fatal and nonfatal strokes, certain types of types of heart surgery, hospitalization for heart failure, and chest pain in patients with heart disease.

It said it is the first cholesterol-lowering drug to win approval for hospitalization for heart failure.

Pfizer shares rose 24 cents to $25.42 in mid morning trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

entry.headline: Microsoft sees billions in sales from VoIP shift
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. sees the shift by business organizations to Web-based phone systems running on its software to generate "billions" of dollars in revenue for the company, a top executive said on Tuesday.

The move to Web-based phone systems will gain momentum during the next three years and Microsoft's new server software will transform the telecommunication systems industry the way its Windows operating system changed the computer industry, said Jeff Raikes, president of Microsoft's business division.

"You're going to see history repeat itself," said Raikes in an interview ahead of a keynote speech at VoiceCon Spring 2007, an industry conference for Web-based telephony.

Microsoft's strategy in addressing the Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) business market differs from that of Cisco Systems Inc. which is selling fully-integrated systems incorporating its network equipment with its own software.

On the other hand Microsoft aims to create a distributed business model like the PC industry with its software at the center. Last year Microsoft and Nortel agreed on a broad alliance to address the VoIP market.

The software segment of a transformation to VoIP will grow to a $35 billion to $40 billion market, according to Raikes, and Microsoft plans to get a piece of the action.

"Ultimately, it will mean billions," said Raikes, who is one of the company's three division presidents.

An increasing number of businesses are adopting VoIP technology in some form, mainly to save costs. Yankee Group's Zeus Kerravala estimates that around 82 percent of U.S. companies use VoIP somewhere in their network, although only 8 percent have fully incorporated the technology.

"Right now, Cisco, Microsoft and Avaya Inc. are basically the main three companies in enterprise VoIP," he said.

The high cost of implementation deters many companies from making a full switch to VoIP systems, but Raikes said the cost of a Web-based phone system will come down by 50 percent within three years.

Microsoft sees its Office business software suite at the center of a new unified communications push that aims to simplify communications for workers bogged down with e-mail, instant messaging, Web and wireless telephony.

The Office suite, which includes Outlook e-mail, Word documents and Excel spreadsheets, is already one of the world's most widely used software applications. It incorporated a "presence" feature within Office 2007 to allow workers to see the availability of another worker for a call or message.

Any time a worker's name shows up on a document or e-mail, there is a icon that allows people to initiate a phone call with one click. This feature, according to Raikes, will save time and improve business processes.

Microsoft predicts over 100 million business users -- twice the size of the current VoIP business user market -- will have the ability to make VoIP phone calls through Office within three years.

Microsoft said it plans to start public testing of its Office Communications, or its unified communications, server and accompanying desktop software later this month.

(Additional reporting by Ritsuko Ando in New York)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-JPMorgan chairman feels no pressure for dealmaking
entry.body:
(Recasts, adds details)

NEW YORK, March 6 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM.N) Chairman Jamie Dimon said on Tuesday that regional bank consolidation in the United States presents such a big opportunity for an acquisition that he feels no pressure to rush into any deal.

Dimon, who runs the third-largest U.S. bank, said his executive team is "acquisition capable" and no longer preoccupied with digesting past acquisitions.

Dimon made his remarks at JPMorgan's investor day in Manhattan.

Some Wall Street analysts expect JPMorgan to buy a large regional bank to expand the company's retail branch footprint in the U.S. South or West, for example.

Dimon didn't say anything to discourage that thinking. As he has said previously, Dimon expects further consolidation among regional banks.

"The opportunity looks so large," Dimon said, that he didn't feel any pressure "to do anything."

For now, Dimon and his team say they are happy to improve productivity and efficiency while generating internal growth in businesses that include investment banking, mortgage lending, credit cards and asset management. He said JPMorgan's franchise in these areas would be hard to duplicate today.

entry.headline: Microsoft eyes day when camera phones aid map searches
entry.body:
REDMOND, Washington (Reuters) - Lost in Seattle with nothing but a camera phone? Just snap a picture of a nearby building, send off the photo to a database and soon you'll get back a map and information about where you are.

The new Web service is one of over 40 new technologies and ideas displayed by Microsoft Corp. at its research department's annual TechFest fair on Tuesday.

Microsoft Research TechFest is the world's largest software maker's chance to show off the talent of its 750 global researchers, who are working on problems ranging from how to use sensors in medical science to how to view high-definition pictures through a Web browser.

The technologies and products on display are at various stages of development. Some are ready to be incorporated into existing products, while others are years away from finding the right application to utilize the technology.

The map-search technology required Microsoft to get millions of street-level pictures of Seattle's buildings and landmarks. Those pictures were added to a database and indexed by distinguishing features that can be cross referenced to pictures sent in by users.

Increasingly sophisticated mobile phones are becoming a popular device to search for maps, directions and other local information and Microsoft said the service is a logical next step.

"When you are using a mobile phone, then inputting text can sometimes be difficult. So we decided to make the camera the input," said Xing Xie, a Microsoft researcher who was demonstrating the technology.

The service is still being tested at Microsoft and releasing the product on a wide scale could prove challenging since the company would need databases full of pictures of buildings in every city.

Other interesting demonstrations included a new Web security application that prevents automated computers from exploiting Internet sites with a quiz to distinguish whether the animal in a picture is a cat or a dog.

It would replace current verification systems that require users to look at an image of garbled text and type out a word or a series of numbers and letter.

Microsoft researcher John Doucher said it is easy for humans to decipher a cat from a dog, but computers running image-reading software often have trouble. This application is ready for use and available for Web developers at asirra.com.

Microsoft also showed off a new type of answering machine. Instead of a conventional machine that displays the number of messages, Microsoft's "Bubble board" displays the messages in floating bubbles on a touch-screen monitor with the caller's picture inside.

Unlike current answering machines that play messages in chronological order, the Bubble board allows the user to choose whose message to hear first by touching the caller's message bubble.

entry.headline: Exxon transfers Angola LNG plant stake to Sonangol
entry.body:
LONDON, March 7 (Reuters) - U.S. oil major Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) has transferred its minority stake in a planned multibillion dollar liquefied natural gas plant in Angola to state-run Sonangol, a company spokesman said on Wednesday.

Exxon has granted Sonangol its 13.6 percent stake in Angola's LNG plant at Soyo, which is expected to cost as much as $5 billion to construct. "Due to recent commercial developments the company has elected to assign its interest to affiliates of Sonangol EP," the spokesman said.

"Exxon Mobil will continue to pursue development opportunities in Angola that will increase shareholder value and support the country's growth objectives," he added.

With the transaction, Sonangol's stake is equal to that of Chevron Corp's (CVX.N) 36.4 percent share.

Other shareholders include Total (TOTF.PA) and BP (BP.L), each with 13.6 percent.

entry.headline: Pfizer: Lipitor receives FDA approval for five new indications in patients with heart disease
entry.body: Co announces that the FDS has approved Lipitor Tablets to reduce the risk of nonfatal heart attacks, fatal and non-fatal strokes, certain types of heart surgery, hospitalization for heart failure, and chest pain in patients with heart disease. Lipitor is the first cholesterol-lowering medication to receive FDA approval for the reduction of the risk of hospitalization for heart failure. This new approval expands the use of Lipitor to patients at high risk for cardiovascular events because of established heart disease such as prior heart attack, prior heart surgery, or chest pain with evidence of clogged arteries. Previously, Lipitor was approved to reduce cardiovascular events in patients without heart disease. The approval is based on results from the landmark TNT trial and supported by findings from the Incremental Decrease in Endpoints through Aggressive Lipid Lowering trial. The five-year TNT study involved 10,000 patients with both heart disease and elevated LDL levels.

entry.headline: Court rules for Dell, Microsoft in Alcatel-Lucent case
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - A U.S. court has ruled that Dell Inc. DELL.O personal-organizer products did not infringe a patent held by Alcatel-Lucent ALU.PA(ALU.N), according to a court document filed online on Thursday.

The court also ruled in the summary judgment that Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) would not be liable for indirect infringement of the patent, according to a filing at the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California.

The decision is the latest in a larger group of patent cases Alcatel-Lucent has taken against the companies. Microsoft has said it would appeal a digital music patent case after a jury told it in February to pay Alcatel-Lucent $1.52 billion.

The summary judgment filed Thursday related to Dell's Axim personal digital assistant products and an Alcatel-Lucent patent for the use of a stylus to control notebook computers.

Many hand held organizers and mobile phones let users navigate through menus or dial a number by tapping a stylus onto the device's screen.

It is part of a group of four patent cases, related to user interface technology, scheduled to go to trial in May.

Alcatel-Lucent spokeswoman Joan Campion said the court still plans go ahead with a patent trial related to tablet computers, which use a stylus to control computer functions.

The court has thrown out two other patent claims tied to the case including one related to Web coding technology and is expected to rule on a fourth patent in April, Microsoft said.

A Dell representative said the company's policy was to decline comment on pending litigation.

Alcatel-Lucent shares closed up 26 cents, or about 2 percent, at $12.12 on the New York Stock Exchange. Microsoft stock slid 29 cents, or more than 1 percent, to $27.32 on Nasdaq, where Dell fell 4 cents, or 0.2 percent, to $22.26.

(Additional reporting by Daisuke Wakabayashi in Seattle)

entry.headline: Disney investors reelect board, reject rights plan
entry.body:
NEW ORLEANS (Reuters) - Shareholders of the Walt Disney Co. (DIS.N) resoundingly reelected the 11-member board but did not pass a "poison pill" proposal on Thursday at the entertainment company's annual meeting in New Orleans.

Investors also voted down a shareholder proposal to strengthen precautions against unsolicited takeover threats, or so-called "greenmail." The company has adopted some of the measures on its own over the past three years, according to Disney board Chairman John Pepper.

A shareholder proposal that would require the board to adopt a "poison pill" to foil hostile takeovers received yes votes from a majority of those who voted but just 43 percent of the shares outstanding -- short of the two-thirds it needed to pass.

The board had recommended that shareholders reject the plan as lacking in flexibility, but Pepper said directors would give "prompt and serious consideration to the matter."

The proposal would have required the board and shareholders to ratify the adoption of a poison pill every year.

Disney has not had a poison pill, also known as a stockholders rights plan, since 1999 and was not considering adopting such a plan, the company's proxy statement said.

Also on Thursday, Disney investors approved an amended version of the company's 2005 stock incentive plan, which increases the number of shares that can be issued by 31 million to 58 million. They also reauthorized a 2002 executive performance plan, which needs approval every five years.

An estimated 400 shareholders attended the meeting at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center in New Orleans.

Disney Chief Executive Robert Iger chose the location, saying he wanted to show the company's support for the city as it recovers from the damage suffered in Hurricane Katrina.

entry.headline: Conoco, Chevron agree May 1 handover in Venezuela
entry.body:
CARACAS (Reuters) - Venezuela said on Thursday U.S. oil giants ConocoPhillips (COP.N) and Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) have agreed to cede by May 1 operations of multibillion-dollar projects in the Orinoco heavy crude belt.

In compliance with a decree issued last month by President Hugo Chavez, the companies will form transition committees to oversee the handover of their projects' operations to state oil company PDVSA.

Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) has already agreed to pass control of its operations to PDVSA by the tight May Day deadline.

Chavez, who is pressing a raft of nationalizations since a December landslide re-election, wants the state to take at least 60 percent of the projects that develop tarry crude in the OPEC nation.

Although he set the May deadline for PDVSA to take the operational helm, he is allowing the foreign investors until almost September to finalize the terms of their stakeholding in the projects.

PDVSA director Eulogio del Pino said in a company statement the committees were being formed "so that the nationalization of these businesses should be finalized by May 1 and that the operations should be transferred from the foreign firms to the Venezuelan state."

The four Orinoco projects, valued at more than $30 billion, turn tar-like oil into around 600,000 barrels per day of lighter synthetic crude.

For years, Chavez, who declares himself an enemy of capitalism, has squeezed foreign oil investments with nationalization moves and taken over some assets in other industries.

But the major oil companies' Orinoco investments are the largest he has taken on since coming to power in 1999. The pace of the takeovers and the absence of open opposition from the companies have surprised political and economic analysts.

There has been no word on whether the Sincor heavy crude project, involving France's Total (TOTF.PA) and Norway's Statoil ASA (STL.OL), will transfer to PDVSA control in the Orinoco.

But Total's chief executive said this week his company regards the Orinoco as a priority and promised to work "shoulder to shoulder" with Venezuela over its investments in the country.

Del Pino also said Conoco agreed to set up a transition body for the May 1 handover of operations in a natural gas field, Corocoro, which is covered by last month's decree too.

LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N), said it hired Andrew Wilkinson, a lawyer from Cadwalader Wickersham Taft LLP, to expand its European restructuring unit.

As managing director, Wilkinson will run the London-based team along with Lachlan Edwards, who was hired from Rothschild ROT.L last summer.

Wilkinson will report to Tim Flynn and Doug Henderson, co-heads of European Leveraged Finance, Goldman Sachs said on Thursday.

Eric Coutts, former co-head of the restructuring unit, left Goldman Sachs last month to work for Citigroup's (C.N) mergers and acquisitions unit in Paris.

Investment banks are expanding their restructuring units as increasing leverage levels and rising interest rates may cause a wave of insolvencies.

entry.headline: Goldman to open Brazil bank eyeing trading profits
entry.body:
SAO PAULO, March 8 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs (GS.N) is set to open a bank in Brazil next week to trade local securities and capture a piece of the booming market for equity underwriting, a source close to the bank said on Thursday.

Goldman Co-President Gary Cohn will come to Sao Paulo for the opening, the firm's biggest move in Brazil since talks broke down to buy local investment bank Pactual.

Cohn will be joined by Jim O'Neill, the Goldman economist who coined the term BRIC to describe the importance of Brazil, Russia, India and China in the global economy.

A spokesman for Goldman in New York declined to comment on two reports in the Brazilian press on Thursday that said the expansion would be announced next week.

Goldman opened its first office in Brazil in 1995, focusing on merger and acquisitions advisory.

The firm has led the MA ranks the past years, but with a Brazilian banking unit Goldman can venture into the lucrative market for trading local securities. Trading of fixed income, currencies and commodities make up most of Goldman's revenue globally and generate most of its profits.

The opening of Goldman's bank follows a record year of share offerings in Brazil in 2006, when companies sold 31.2 billion reais ($14.8 billion) worth of stock. Stock sales have broken record volumes yearly since 2004, when they totaled 9.15 billion reais.

So far in 2007, nine companies have sold 7.13 billion reais worth of stock, putting share sales on pace to rise 35 percent from last year.

Goldman held talks for more than a year to buy a stake in Brazilian firm Pactual, but Swiss firm UBS AG (UBSN.VX) snapped up Pactual in May 2006 for about $2.5 billion. ($1 = 2.108 reais)

March 8 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs said the U.S. real estate investment trust (REIT) industry is suffering from a "temporary hangover" flowing a influx of short-term capital, adding investors should take a defensive stance in the sector.

The brokerage downgraded the apartment sector to "underweight" and raised strip centers to "market weight", in line with its recommendation that investors focus on sectors with longer average lease terms and low rollover over the next few years, such as retail and office.

Goldman raised ratings on retail REITs Kimco Realty Corp. (KIM.N) and Taubman Centers Inc. (TCO.N) to "buy" from "neutral" to reflect its more optimistic near-term view on the sector.

It downgraded apartment REITs Archstone-Smith Trust (ASN.N) to "neutral" from "buy" and Equity Residential (EQR.N) to "sell" from "neutral", reflecting its more cautious stance on the sector.

Goldman said the fundamental drivers of REIT share prices remain in place but with the U.S. economy slowing, REITs with shorter average lease terms will be the first to experience deteriorations in cash flow growth. (Reporting by Neha Singh in Bangalore)

entry.headline: Exxon sees spending of $20 billion a year through 2011
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) plans to spend about $20 billion annually through 2011 and start production at 25 major oil and gas projects over the next three years, the world's largest publicly traded oil company said on Wednesday.

The projects will add about 1 million barrels of oil equivalent per day (BOEPD) to its base volumes when they reach their peak, Exxon Mobil said. The company was producing about 4.2 million BOEPD at the end of 2006.

Still, the company's projected oil and gas production capacity toward the end of the decade is lower than last year's estimate due to delayed projects, divestments and changes to production sharing agreements at some of its projects.

Chief Executive Rex Tillerson, speaking at the company's analyst meeting in New York, said he expects company capital spending to be at around the $20 billion level a year through 2011.

"I expect very active levels of investment beyond the end of the decade," Tillerson said.

Exxon Mobil's capital spending in 2006 was about $19.9 billion.

Exxon posted the largest corporate profit in U.S. history in 2006 thanks to record high crude oil prices.

The oil industry's costs also have climbed, as high oil prices have fueled demand for drilling rigs, steel and other materials.

Tillerson said the company has seen a 9 to 10 percent increase in drilling costs over the past year or so.

"Rig rates are not likely to abate until some of the new rigs that are being built come out of the yard," which should happen over the next two or three years, he said, speaking to reporters after the meeting.

Costs seem "to maybe have reached a plateau. We're not going to see the same year over year increase," Tillerson said.

Oil prices rose nearly 2 percent on Wednesday, pushing up energy stocks. Exxon's shares rose nearly 1 percent on the New York Stock Exchange to $71.64.

SEVEN NEW PROJECTS IN 2007

Exxon Mobil Senior Vice President Stuart McGill said the company plans to start production at seven new projects in 2007 that will add about 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to the company's base volumes.

The projects the company plans to bring on line this year include four projects in Europe, two projects in Angola, and a liquefied natural gas (LNG) unit at its RasGas project in Qatar.

It plans to start up 18 additional projects over the course of 2008 and 2009, including the company's Thunder Horse joint venture with BP Plc (BP.L) in the Gulf of Mexico, several projects in Qatar and West Africa, and three LNG terminals.

The company also said it has more than 30 other major projects it plans to start up in 2010 or later. It said its current project inventory is expected to produce 24 billion oil-equivalent barrels over the life of the projects.

Exxon said it expects its production capacity to rise to less than 5 million BOEPD in 2011.

Last year, the company had projected its 2010 production capacity would be close to 5 million BOEPD. Several of the companies projects have since been delayed, including Thunder Horse and the huge Kashagan oil field in Kazakhstan.

(Additional reporting by Euan Rocha and Michele Gershberg)

entry.headline: Goldman, Leighton in Alinta shortlist-sources
entry.body:
SYDNEY, March 8 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs (GS.N), Leighton Holdings Ltd. (LEI.AX) and Singapore Power are among parties shortlisted to bid for Australian energy infrastructure group Alinta AAN.AX, sources familiar with the situation said.

Alinta, which is looking to flush out rival offers to a management buyout proposal, expects to call for final bids by the end of March but no dates have been set, sources told Reuters.

"Alinta hopes to have something happening by the end of the month," one of the sources said, adding Alinta did not want to be tied down to a particular date.

At least three groups -- Australian investment bank Babcock Brown Ltd. BNB.AX in partnership with Singapore Power, U.S. investment bank Goldman Sachs (GS.N) and Australian engineering contractor Leighton Holdings Ltd. (LEI.AX) -- were conducting due diligence, the sources said.

Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd's (1038.HK) Spark Infrastructure (SKI.AX), which has said it may be interested in some Alinta assets, was not involved, one source said. A Spark spokesman declined to comment.

A number of proposals from other parties were rejected by Alinta's advisers because they "did not stack up", one of the sources said.

Perth-based Alinta put itself up for sale in January after receiving a controversial buyout proposal from its top five executives. It said last month it had received expressions of interest from several partie,s but no firm bids.

Alinta shares rose on Monday following a Bloomberg report which said the Babcock-Singapore Power team planned to bid A$9 billion ($7 billion) for Alinta. Babcock later said the report was unfounded.

Sources said Thursday a bid at $9 billion Singapore dollars ($5.9 billion), or about A$15.20 per share, was more credible.

However, Babcock and Singapore Power were still conducting due diligence and there were no figures on the table, another source said.

The buyout proposal, which saw former adviser Macquarie Bank Ltd. MBL.AX also advising the management buyout group, became mired in controversy due to potential conflicts of interest.

Alinta sacked Macquarie as its adviser in February and laid down conditions for the bank's continued role in advising the buyout group. Macquarie agreed to the terms.

The company bought infrastructure assets from energy retailer AGL Energy Ltd. AGL.AX last year. It operates a network of gas pipelines and gas-fired power stations and gas transmission pipelines.

JP Morgan and Carnegie Wylie are advising Alinta.

Alinta shares were trading 0.7 percent firmer at A$14.57 a share by 0352 GMT in a slightly easier overall market. (Additional reporting by Jan Dahinten in Singapore) ($1=A$1.29) ($1=1.525 Singapore Dollar)

entry.headline: For Disney's Iger, New Orleans meeting is personal
entry.body:
NEW ORLEANS (Reuters) - For Walt Disney Co. chief Robert Iger, the decision to hold the entertainment giant's annual shareholder meeting in New Orleans on Thursday 18 months after Hurricane Katrina was as much personal as professional.

Among the thousands who lost homes when the devastating storm struck the historic Gulf Coast city on August 29, 2005, were the uncle and brother of Iger's wife.

Iger, who had not been to New Orleans since Katrina struck, toured storm-damaged areas shortly after arriving on Wednesday and viewed rebuilding efforts, including those of his brother-in-law.

In an interview with Reuters, the Disney chief executive said the California-based company's decision to stage the annual meeting in New Orleans "was not only a professional arrangement, it was also very personal."

The city is still struggling to rebuild after Katrina, which caused massive flooding and killed about 1,300 people.

"We thought it would be a great signal to send that New Orleans is important, that we believe in New Orleans and in a way it was our means of not only expressing some appreciation but of giving back," Iger said.

The company announced at its annual meeting that its new animated film, "The Frog Princess," would be set in the French Quarter of New Orleans.

Iger said it was "pretty devastating" seeing the lingering damage from Katrina.

"You can't appreciate the level of devastation until you see it up close, and I was almost shocked at that," Iger said. "It's also disturbing to see entire city blocks, blocks of houses that are completely empty or in some areas, people living in FEMA trailers."

"On the other hand, you see new houses, new trees, fresh flowers cropped up and signs of life in a lot of places that a year ago you never could have expected that to happen."

entry.headline: Coca-Cola CEO got $7 mln in salary,performance pay
entry.body:
CHICAGO (Reuters) - Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N) Chairman and Chief Executive E. Neville Isdell received $7 million in salary and performance-based pay in 2006, nearly 17 percent more than he was paid a year earlier, the world's largest soft drink company said on Friday.

Isdell's salary was unchanged at $1.5 million but his $5.5 million in incentive compensation for 2006 was $1 million higher than 2005, according to Coke's proxy filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Including awards of stock, options, pension value, deferred compensation and all other benefits, Isdell's total 2006 compensation under new SEC disclosure requirements was $32.3 million, compared to an estimated $26.1 million in 2005, if the new rules had been in effect at that time.

Isdell, 63, was named to Coca-Cola's top job in June 2004.

He received $12.1 million worth of stock awards and $7.3 million worth option awards in 2006, after receiving $7.3 million in stock awards and $10.8 million in option awards in 2005, Coke said.

Part of the larger total compensation figure stems from the amount Coke accrued for Isdell's pension, which the company had not previously disclosed. Coke said it accrued nearly $5.4 million for the pension in 2006, up from $1.4 million in 2005.

Isdell's compensation actually received for 2006, excluding items such as stock awards which have not been paid out yet, was $7.5 million. Under the old rules, Isdell's 2005 compensation was about $6.5 million, Coke said.

The compensation committee kept Isdell's base salary unchanged after deciding that it was at a competitive level and that any adjustments to his 2006 compensation should focus on long-term responsibilities, the company said in the filing.

Coke said Isdell's incentive award was based on the company's strong performance during 2006, including results at the top end of its long-term volume and profit goals.

The company's unit case volume and net income each rose 4 percent in 2006.

Atlanta-based Coke said it plans to hold its annual meeting on April 18 in Wilmington, Delaware. At the meeting, shareholders will vote on whether to reelect the company's 11 board members, approve a performance incentive plan and vote on five shareholder proposals.

The board recommended that shareholders vote against all five of the shareholder proposals.

Shares of Coke, a component of the Dow Jones industrial average .DJI, rose 43 cents to $47.58 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Coca-Cola trades at about 16.8 times expected 2008 earnings, compared with a multiple of 17.2 for rival PepsiCo Inc. (PEP.N), according to Reuters data.

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-Court rules for Dell, Microsoft in Alcatel-Lucent case
entry.body:
(Adds details, closing share prices)

NEW YORK, March 8 (Reuters) - A U.S. court has ruled that Dell Inc. DELL.O personal-organizer products did not infringe a patent held by Alcatel-Lucent ALU.PA(ALU.N), according to a court document filed online on Thursday.

The court also ruled in the summary judgment that Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) would not be liable for indirect infringement of the patent, according to a filing at the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California.

The decision is the latest in a larger group of patent cases Alcatel-Lucent has taken against the companies. Microsoft has said it would appeal a digital music patent case after a jury told it in February to pay Alcatel-Lucent $1.52 billion. The summary judgment filed Thursday related to Dell's Axim personal digital assistant products and an Alcatel-Lucent patent for the use of a stylus to control notebook computers.

Many hand held organizers and mobile phones let users navigate through menus or dial a number by tapping a stylus onto the device's screen.

It is part of a group of four patent cases, related to user interface technology, scheduled to go to trial in May.

Alcatel-Lucent spokeswoman Joan Campion said the court still plans go ahead with a patent trial related to tablet computers, which use a stylus to control computer functions.

The court has thrown out two other patent claims tied to the case including one related to Web coding technology and is expected to rule on a fourth patent in April, Microsoft said.

A Dell representative said the company's policy was to decline comment on pending litigation.

Alcatel-Lucent shares closed up 26 cents, or about 2 percent, at $12.12 on the New York Stock Exchange. Microsoft stock slid 29 cents, or more than 1 percent, to $27.32 on Nasdaq, where Dell fell 4 cents, or 0.2 percent, to $22.26.

(Additional reporting by Daisuke Wakabayashi in Seattle)

TOKYO, March 11 (Reuters) - Japanese insurer Millea Holdings Inc. (8766.T) will set up a reinsurance company jointly with JP Morgan (JPM.N), financial daily Nikkei said on Sunday.

The new firm, which will have start-up capital of about 10 billion yen ($84.56 million), with Millea owning a majority, will offer reinsurance services to cover the risk faced by life insurers offering variable annuity policies.

The Nikkei said Millea is likely to be the first Japanese insurer to reinsure against the risk in variable annuity contracts.

A formal announcement on the venture is expected on Monday.

Variable annuity policyholders receive different amounts of money at maturity depending on the performance of their investment trusts.

entry.headline: Microsoft adds Office parts to enterprise software
entry.body:
SEATTLE, March 12 (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) introduced a new product on Monday that incorporates features of its mainstay Office applications in a bid to gain share in the enterprise market dominated by Oracle Corp. ORCL.O and SAP (SAPG.DE).

The world's largest software maker aims to use people's familiarity with Office applications to spread the reach of its Microsoft Dynamics business software.

The new products, Microsoft Dynamics Client for Microsoft Office, are designed to drive growth at its enterprise software segment, which generated $900 million in sales in its fiscal year ended in June.

The new products are targeted at workers who do not have access to information and data contained within enterprise software, Microsoft said. According to a study cited by Microsoft, about 85 percent of workers do not have direct access to enterprise software.

One of the 12 new applications available in the new software is a project time and expense system, which allows workers to log the amount of time spent on a project through Outlook e-mail and calendar systems.

Microsoft's high-end enterprise software licenses can cost as much as $4000 per seat, but the Office versions cost $195 a seat for standard computers or $395 a seat for servers running its SharePoint collaboration software.

Shares of Microsoft were up 4 cents to $27.33 in midday trade on the Nasdaq.

entry.headline: Schering-Plough bets on Pfizer cast-off drug
entry.body:
By Toni Clarke

BOSTON, March 12 (Reuters) - Schering-Plough Corp. SGP.N is betting it can successfully develop an experimental schizophrenia drug recently cast off by Pfizer Inc. (PFE.N), but analysts are skeptical.

The drug, asenapine, was acquired by Schering-Plough as part of its $14.4 billion purchase of Organon BioSciences, and constituted an important part of the transaction, which was announced on Monday.

"We think this is a very well-tolerated agent and we think it will be competitive," said Fred Hassan, Schering-Plough's chief executive, on a conference call with analysts.

But industry experts are less sure.

"This really offers us nothing new or better than currently available treatments and it may have some less favorable qualities," said Dr. Jeffrey Lieberman, chairman of psychiatry at Columbia University.

Last November Pfizer, the world's biggest drugmaker, ended a collaboration with Organon, the pharmaceuticals division of Akzo Nobel (AKZO.AS), after results of late-stage clinical trials of asenapine proved mixed.

But Hassan said that of the five late-stage experimental compounds acquired with the acquisition of Organon, asenapine is one of the most attractive.

"We see this as a promising central nervous system compound and one that will allow us to become a major player in this market," he said.

Asenapine is one of a class of drugs known as 5HT/D2 antagonists which include Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ.N) Risperdal and Eli Lilly & Co.'s (LLY.N) Zyprexa. They work by suppressing excess levels of the brain chemicals serotonin and dopamine, thought to be associated with some of the so-called "positive" symptoms of schizophrenia such as hallucinations.

The $10-billion-plus market for antipsychotic drugs is competitive and crowded but characterized by much switching between products as no drug works well for all patients.

Even so, analysts are not convinced asenapine will realize the promise many had once held out for it.

"Pfizer pulling out doesn't mean the drug is hopeless, it could still do quite well, but it's not likely to be the huge blockbuster that Pfizer thought it would be," said Nitasha Manchanda, an analyst at market research firm Decision Resources. "The trial results so far are not encouraging."

Pfizer has said it withdrew from the partnership for commercial reasons.

Hassan said Schering-Plough has a different view.

"Every company makes its own judgments," he said.

((Reporting by Toni Clarke; editing by Deborah Cohen; Reuters Messaging, toni.clarke.reuters.com@reuters.net, 617-367-4165)) Keywords: SCHERINGPLOUGH/ASENAPINE

entry.headline: EMC, IBM grew fastest in storage computers in Q4
entry.body:
SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 (Reuters) - EMC Corp. (EMC.N) and International Business Machines Corp. (IBM.N) posted the fastest revenue growth in data-storage computers in the fourth quarter, market researcher IDC said on Monday.

EMC held the No. 1 market spot in IDC's quarterly survey of data-storage vendors, with 22.1 percent of the $4.8 billion market, up from 21.3 percent a year earlier. IBM had 18.6 percent of the market, up from 17.1 percent.

EMC's revenue from storage grew 10 percent in the fourth quarter. IBM's revenue grew 15.5 percent, the fastest of the major vendors, IDC said.

Hewlett-Packard Co.'s (HPQ.N) market share slipped to 13.7 percent from 15 percent, giving it the No. 3 spot in the ranking, and Dell Inc. DELL.O fell to 8.1 percent from 9.5 percent of the market. Dell's storage revenue fell 8.8 percent, the most of any major vendor, according to IDC.

Overall market sales were driven by demand for network storage systems between $15,000 and $149,999, a "sweet spot" for vendors in 2006, IDC research manager Natalya Yezhkova said in a statement. Such systems grew at a double-digit percentage rate and outsold the higher-priced segment during all four quarters of last year.

entry.headline: Cisco, IBM to merge maintenance services abroad
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Cisco Systems Inc. and International Business Machines Corp. said on Monday they will combine technical support services for mutual customers, highlighting increasingly close ties between the network equipment maker and computer services company.

Customers of both companies in 46 countries, including Australia, China, Germany and the United Kingdom, will now have common IT support centers that will respond to queries and maintenance requests for both Cisco and IBM products.

The two companies already have a similar agreement in the United States.

"Customers won't have to choose between going to IBM or Cisco for IT support," said Robert Kritzer, vice president of IBM Global Services.

San Jose, California-based Cisco has expanded its focus from routers and switches to a broader range of equipment and software in recent years, and has stepped up its alliance with IBM.

One area of collaboration has been in making their products, ranging from software to network equipment and other hardware, work together.

Cisco said last week it was working with IBM to further develop its Unified Communications system, a package of software and equipment that link desktop computers, office phones and mobile devices.

Cisco has also been boosting its partnership with Microsoft Corp. to develop the Unified Communications system, despite growing rivalry between the two companies in areas such as Internet security and Web-based telephone technology, known as voice-over-Internet protocol (VOIP).

entry.headline: Goldman Sachs beefs up Europe private equity team
entry.body:
LONDON, March 12 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs (GS.N) is relocating investment banker John Waldron to London from New York to co-head the group that advises private equity firms, another signal of the sector's growing significance in Europe.

Waldron will work with Richard Campell-Breeden starting April 1, Goldman Sachs said on Monday, to broaden the bank's relationships with private equity firms, which are among the top fee-generating clients for deal advisers.

Private equity firms, which borrow large sums of money to help finance takeovers of publicly listed companies, have been increasingly targeting deals in Europe.

A group of four buyout firms is contemplating a 10 billion pound ($19.4 billion) takeover of supermarket group J. Sainsbury (SBRY.L) and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts [KKR.UL] said on Friday it had made a 9.7 billion pound approach to buy pharmacy chain owner Alliance Boots AB.L.

Goldman is advising the consortium on Sainsbury and Alliance Boots on the approach.

Waldron joined the bank in 2000 to work on media and technology deals and transferred to become co-head of leveraged finance in 2005.

Charlie Bott, who had been co-head of the bank's financial sponsors group in London, will now become chairman of it.

Meanwhile, Tom Connolly, Tim Flynn and Doug Henderson will remain in leadership roles with the leveraged finance group in New York, Goldman Sachs said.

entry.headline: Chevron sees output growth, but costs threaten
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) said on Tuesday its developing oil and natural gas projects could produce about 1.1 million barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2011, but surging costs may threaten some of the ventures.

The second-largest U.S. oil company raised cost estimates for several of its huge projects and pulled previously disclosed cost projections for many others, as it evaluates those projects to see which are viable.

"The projects that are still in the evaluation phase are clearly going to be impacted by higher costs and we have to make choices," Chief Executive Dave O'Reilly said at the company's analyst meeting in New York.

"We're not going to invest in projects unless we can create value from them," he said.

Oil industry costs have soared in recent years as booming crude oil prices have fueled demand for drilling rigs, steel and other materials.

The company raised its cost projections for projects including its Athabasca oil sands project expansion in Canada, as well as projects in Indonesia and Kazakhstan.

It declined to give projections for 11 projects expected to start production by the end of 2012. One project for which it pulled a cost forecast was the Gorgon gas field offshore Australia.

Last year, Chevron forecast that the project would cost the company $10.4 billion.

O'Reilly said the company was reevaluating the Gorgon project due to the costs, but is confident that Chevron will eventually have a project there.

MORE THAN 3 PCT PRODUCTION GROWTH

Chevron said production from its developing projects will give the company average annual output growth of at least 3 percent through 2010. It is making progress on more than 30 oil and gas development projects in which it is investing at least $1 billion each.

Those projects would contribute to an average proved reserves replacement rate of more than 100 percent for the next five years.

"Chevron has a great slate of projects, but it is going to be very challenging to bring them all on line," said independent analyst Kurt Wulff.

Chevron's total capital spending for 2007 is still expected to be $19.6 billion, with 39 percent of that in North America, 25 percent in Africa, 19 percent in Asia-Pacific, 7 percent in the Caspian region, and 10 percent in the rest of the world.

Wulff pointed out that Chevron is spending nearly as much as its much larger rival Exxon Mobil (XOM.N), which plans to shell out about $20 billion in 2007.

"Investors can expect more growth from Chevron," he said.

Chevron also plans to keep exploration spending high in the coming years.

Spending on exploration would be "at a higher level than it's been in the past," Bobby Ryan, vice president for global exploration, told analysts, although the estimated $2 billion in spending for 2007 would be less than in 2006.

In its refining operations, Chevron is seeking to add flexibility to its plants to process heavier and higher-sulphur crude oils.

The company said it plans to selectively divest assets, which will give it a more focused footprint with a strong presence in fewer locations.

Shares of Chevron fell 99 cents, or 1.4 percent, to close at $67.84 on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday as oil prices dipped about 1.3 percent.

(Additional reporting by Matt Daily)

entry.headline: Chevron drops proposed LNG project off Mexico
entry.body:
LOS ANGELES, March 13 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) said on Tuesday it is dropping plans for a liquefied natural gas terminal off the Baja California coast of Mexico, near the U.S. border.

The oil major canceled three permits with Mexican officials because the project no longer fits Chevron's business needs, said Margaret Cooper, a Chevron spokeswoman.

"The project was originally developed with the intent that (the terminal) could receive supply from Chevron's share of LNG from the proposed Gorgon project off Australia," Cooper said. "But Chevron has found supply agreements for the majority of our (share of Gorgon) with three customers in Japan."

Those three customers are Chubu Electric Power Co. (9502.T), Osaka Gas Co. (9532.T) and Tokyo Gas Co. Ltd. (9531.T). Each signed 25-year deals in 2005.

Chubu Electric's deal begins in 2010 and is for 1.5 million tonnes per year, Osaka Gas is to get 1.5 million tonnes annually starting in 2011, and Tokyo Gas has signed on for 1.2 million tonnes per year starting in 2010, Chevron has said.

The canceled $650 million, 1.4 billion-cubic-feet-per-day terminal was to be located off the Coronado Islands.

LNG terminals on the West Coast face stiff environmental opposition. The Chevron terminal would have been near the site of six threatened or endangered species of seabirds as well as plants that are not found elsewhere on earth.

Chevron will operate the Gorgon project off northwest Australia, in which it has a 50 percent stake. Chevron said three years ago the cost to develop the field, estimated to have about 12.9 trillion cubic feet of gas, is $11 billion. Chevron's partners in the project are Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM.N) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSa.L).

Cooper said Chevron's decision was not because of competing LNG gas terminals proposed for the U.S. West Coast, including Sempra Energy's (SRE.N) Energia Costa Azul LNG terminal, due to open in 2008. Sempra said last month construction of the terminal was 65 percent complete.

LNG is natural gas that is cooled to extreme temperatures and then shipped via tankers. It is vaporized back to a natural gas state at receiving terminals.

In a meeting with financial analysts in New York on Tuesday, Chevron Chief Executive Dave O'Reilly said it was reevaluating the Gorgon project due to its cost, but it is confident that Chevron will eventually have a project there.

entry.headline: Microsoft in talks to buy Tellme Networks: sources
entry.body:
NEW YORK/SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) is in talks to buy Tellme Networks Inc., the privately owned voice recognition technology company, two sources familiar with the situation said on Tuesday.

A deal could value Tellme at more than $800 million, one of the sources said. A second source said the two sides were close to a deal, which could be announced later this week.

Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, and Tellme declined comment. The talks were first reported by technology news Web site CNET News.

Tellme is a dot-com survivor that has built up a major presence in the U.S. directory assistance market.

Tellme was founded in 1999 by Mike McCue, previously vice president of technology at Netscape, according to Tellme's Web site.

Tellme relies on speech recognition technology from a variety of suppliers including Nuance Communications Inc. (NUAN.O). However, Microsoft has recently been promoting its own speech recognition technology, which it sells for both computer users and customer call centers.

Nuance's shares closed down 4.5 percent to $13.39, while Microsoft fell 2.6 percent at $26.72, both on Nasdaq.

Tellme is privately owned by its employees and investors that include venture capital firms Benchmark Capital and Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, according to the investors' Web sites.

Tellme's voice recognition technology allows users to gather information from the Internet over the telephone. The Mountain View, California-based company also offers services to businesses looking to automate directory assistance and other phone functions.

The company provides automated phone services for companies, including Merrill Lynch, Cingular and Federal Express, serving over 40 million people every month.

One of the sources said Tellme would be especially appealing to Microsoft in the area of wireless search, or search using a mobile phone.

The software giant sees mobile phone searches as a relatively untapped market where it can compete more favorably with Google Inc. (GOOG.O), the dominant leader in computer-based searches.

One of the hurdles to mobile search has been how best to enter the information sought by a user. Tellme's voice recognition capabilities could be added to Microsoft's Windows Mobile operating system for cell phones.

(Additional reporting by Eric Auchard in New York)

entry.headline: UPDATE 3-Goldman quarterly earnings rise to a record
entry.body:
(Adds details, comment)

By Joseph A. Giannone

NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) posted its best quarterly earnings ever on Tuesday, trouncing expectations as record trading and banking results showed that recent mortgage woes and stock volatility had little impact.

Still Goldman shares were off on a day when the broader U.S. stock market was down 1 percent, as investors pulled out of riskier investments amid persistent worries that subprime mortgage woes would spread to other markets.

The largest investment bank by market value said net earnings rose 29 percent to a record $3.20 billion, or $6.67 a share, in the fiscal first quarter that ended Feb. 23, up from of $2.48 billion, or $5.08 a share, a year ago. Net revenue rose 22 percent to a record $12.73 billion.

The results exceeded the average analyst forecast of $4.97 a share, according to Reuters Estimates.

"While upside surprises have been the norm for Goldman, we believe the magnitude was probably better than the market expected," Fox-Pitt Kelton analyst David Trone said.

After Wall Street firms delivered a third year of record profit in 2006, analysts and bank executives cautioned that the industry faced a more uncertain environment. Those fears were fanned last month when a slump in Chinese stocks triggered a sell-off worldwide.

Meanwhile subprime lenders are going under as loan defaults rose and as financiers, including Goldman, cut off funding. New Century Financial (NEWC.PK), the largest independent subprime lender, is teetering near bankruptcy and investors worry rivals won't be far behind.

Goldman shares were off $1.46, or 0.7 percent, at $201.14. Shares of Lehman Brothers Holding Corp. LEH.N, which reports its results on Wednesday, fell $2.80, or 3.7 percent to $73.75. Morgan Stanley (MS.N), which announces its earnings next week, fell 3.2 percent to $73.63 a share.

SO FAR, SO GOOD

Goldman Chief Financial Officer David Viniar played down the subprime concerns, noting fears about the impact on Goldman's business so far have been overblown. Fixed income trading rose across the board during the quarter, he said, and the firm has not yet seen signs that subprime woes have spread to other debt markets.

"Even our mortgage business was up despite the obviously more challenging subprime market," Viniar said. "Mortgage is a strategically important business to Goldman Sachs, but it's still modest in size compared with the overall firm."

Analysts also note that the stock market swoon and the accelerating demise of subprime lenders have taken place after the close of Goldman's quarters.

For the fiscal first quarter, fixed-income currency and commodity trading generated a record $4.6 billion in net revenue, with strong performance across credit, interest rate, commodity and mortgage markets. Equities trading posted revenue of $3.09 billion, up 26 percent to a record.

"The strength of the results should help to calm investor concerns about the resiliency of global capital markets activity levels," said Sandler O'Neill analyst Jeff Harte, who has a "buy" rating on Goldman shares.

Daily value-at-risk across Goldman's trading businesses rose to $127 million from $106 million in the fourth quarter, reflecting an increase in proprietary risk-taking and more active trading activity, Viniar said.

The quarter also enjoyed a boost from principal investment gains, which surged to $1.73 billion thanks to stakes in Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (1398.HK), Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (8316.T) and $500 million in gains related to a new accounting policy.

PIPELINES FULL

Investment banking posted a record quarter, with revenue rising 17 percent to $1.72 billion on record M and debt underwriting fees. Goldman this year leads the industry in announced M transactions worldwide.

Viniar noted that the backlog of pending merger and underwriting business grew during the quarter to its highest level since 2000, after the peak of the 1990s bull market.

One disappointment came in asset management, where revenue fell 28 percent to $1.07 billion following poor performance in Goldman's giant Global Alpha hedge fund last year. Overall managed assets grew 26 percent to a record $719 billion, though analysts noted fund flows to alternative investments slowed.

Viniar didn't comment on outlook, but noted "conditions that have fueled the growth of our business in these past few years remain very much intact," citing economic growth, low inflation, low interest rates and tight credit spreads.

(Additional reporting by Christian Plumb)

entry.headline: D.Telekom hires JPMorgan to sell Spanish unit-sources
entry.body:
(Adds details)

MADRID, March 13 (Reuters) - Deutsche Telekom (DTEGn.DE), Europe's largest phone operator, has hired JPMorgan (JPM.N) to look for a buyer for its Spanish unit ya.com, sources close to the process said on Tuesday.

"They have sent us the sale prospectus and it seems like they're in a hurry", one of the possible interested buyers told Reuters. Another source familiar with the proceedings told Reuters that JP Morgan had already given the sales documentation to Jazztel (JAZ.MC), Spain's number-two broadband provider, and to mobile-phone operators Orange FTE.PA and Vodafone (VOD.L).

Deutsche Telekom is considering selling the Spanish broadband provider, but has not made a decision yet and may keep the business, a spokesman said, declining to say whether the company had mandated a bank to find a buyer. JP Morgan also declined to comment.

The German phone company is reviewing the sale of several assets, including ya.com, which it bought for 550 million euros

($725 million) in 2000, as Chief Executive Rene Obermann seeks to revive profitability at the former state company.

Obermann had to slash the group's earnings forecasts for last year and for this year as the company lost clients to cheaper competitors in Germany.

Other assets it may sell include Internet companies in France and radio towers in Germany as well as the United States, it said March 1. Ya.com is Spain's fourth-largest broadband provider.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Chevron investment in Venezuela hinges on talks
entry.body:
(Adds detail)

NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp.'s (CVX.N) plans for future investment in Venezuela depend on the outcome of talks with the country's government over its stake in a heavy oil project, Chief Executive Dave O'Reilly said on Tuesday.

"Our appetite very much depends on how we're treated in the current negotiations," he said, speaking at the company's analyst meeting in New York.

Venezuela is attempting to strip majority control of multibillion dollar heavy oil projects in the Orinoco region from some of the world's biggest oil companies.

Chevron owns a 30 percent stake of the Hamaca project in Orinoco and ConocoPhillips (COP.N) owns 40 percent of the venture. Venezuelan state oil firm PDVSA holds the remaining 30 percent, but leftist President Hugo Chavez has said he plans for the state to control at least 60 percent of the Orinoco projects.

O'Reilly said Chevron intends to comply with the Venezuelan government's request to turn over operations at its Hamaca heavy oil joint venture in the Orinoco region to state oil firm PDVSA by a May 1 deadline.

"There is still a period of early negotiation going on -- we don't know how its going to turn out," O'Reilly told reporters after the meeting.

"The only thing I can say is that our production is very, very low," he said.

Chevron produces about 37,000 barrels per day at Hamaca, he said.

The Venezuelan government has warned that it will not pay in cash for the takeovers. It wants to compensate the companies with payments in oil.

O'Reilly said it was too early to speculate whether the company would accept oil as compensation for any changes to its stake in the project.

entry.headline: Goldman quarterly earnings rise to a record
entry.body:
(Adds details, estimates)

By Joseph A. Giannone

NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N), the largest investment bank by market value, said on Tuesday its quarterly earnings rose to a record, trouncing expectations despite recent fears that mortgage market woes and flagging stocks would hurt results.

The world's top merger advisor said net earnings increased to a record $3.20 billion, or $6.67 a share, in the fiscal first quarter ended Feb. 23, up from of $2.48 billion, or $5.08 a share, in the year-ago period. Net revenue rose 22 percent to a record $12.73 billion.

The results exceeded the average analyst forecast of $4.90 a share, according to Reuters Estimates.

Goldman kicked off the first-quarter reporting period for investment banks following weeks of growing uncertainty about the outlook of financial markets worldwide.

After Wall Street firms delivered a third year of record profit in 2006, analysts and bank executives cautioned that the industry faces a more difficult environment marked by worries about economic growth.

But instead of reporting a decline in profit, Goldman's return on equity zoomed to 38 percent in the quarter, which is traditionally the strongest of the year.

"It puts people's minds at ease," with regard to recent worries, said Sandler O'Neill analyst Jeff Harte, who has a "buy" rating on Goldman shares.

The bank remains the most successful trading house and the most active merger adviser worldwide and has reaped big profits from investing its own money.

Fixed income currency and commodity trading generated a record $4.6 billion in net revenue, with strong performance across all major businesses. Equities trading also posted record revenue of $3.09 billion, up 26 percent.

Goldman also reported $1.73 billion in revenue from principal investments, which included $500 million in gains related to the adoption of a new accounting policy.

Investment banking revenue rose 17 percent to $1.72 billion, including record M and debt underwriting fees. Goldman's asset management arm likewise generated record revenue of $1.07 billion, with managed assets growing 26 percent to $719 billion.

Shares of Goldman plunged nearly 9 percent on Feb. 27 after a slump in Chinese stocks triggered a sell-off around the world, combined with growing concerns that subprime woes could lead to broader problems in debt markets.

The shares are up 1.63 percent this year, outperforming the 3 percent decline by the AMEX Securities Broker-Dealer Index.

Sandler analyst Harte noted that after the recent pullback, Goldman shares are "actually kind of cheap, given the earnings they're posting."

(Additional reporting by Christian Plumb)

entry.headline: Portland General Electric says to receive $27 mln as settlement
entry.body:
March 13 (Reuters) - Portland General Electric Co. (POR.N) said it will receive about $27 million as part of a settlement with certain parties in California related to power sales it had made during the west coast energy crisis of 2000 and 2001.

The settlement was filed on Tuesday with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and is subject to approval, the electric utility said in a statement.

With FERC approval of the settlement, the company said it will record a pre-tax increase to income of about $4 million to $5 million. (Reporting by Esha Dey in Bangalore)

entry.headline: Chevron not interested in Shtokman contractor role
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp (CVX.N) Chief Executive Dave O'Reilly said on Tuesday that the company would not be interested in taking on a contractor role at Gazprom's (GAZP.MM) giant Shtokman gas field.

"We've communicated that," he said, speaking at a press conference following the company's analyst meeting.

Last year Gazprom scrapped a yearlong bidding process, saying it would develop Shtokman without any foreign equity partners. Later, Gazprom said it would use foreign contractors but would not offer them any equity in the project.

O'Reilly also said Chevron intends to comply with the Venezuelan government's request to turn over operations at its Hamaca heavy oil joint venture in the Orinoco region to state oil firm PDVSA by a May 1 deadline.

entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) on Tuesday posted its best quarterly earnings ever on record trading and banking results, trouncing expectations that were recently lowered amid fears that mortgage market woes and volatile stocks would hurt results.

The largest investment bank by market value said net earnings increased to a record $3.20 billion, or $6.67 a share, in the fiscal first quarter ended February 23, up from $2.48 billion, or $5.08 a share, in the year-ago period. Net revenue rose 22 percent to a record $12.73 billion, fueled by gains in nearly every business.

The results exceeded the average analyst forecast of $4.97 a share, according to Reuters Estimates. Goldman stock rose $5.40, or 2.7 percent, to $208 in morning trade.

"It was clearly an exceptional first quarter," Goldman Chief Financial Officer David Viniar said.

After Wall Street firms delivered a third year of record profit in 2006, analysts and bank executives cautioned that the industry faced a more difficult environment marked by worries about economic growth. Those fears were fanned last month when a slump in Chinese stocks triggered a sell off worldwide.

Meanwhile subprime lenders have been going under as defaults on loans to people with weak credit rise and as financiers, including Goldman, cut off funds.

Yet instead of reporting a decline in profit, following weeks of uncertainty about the outlook for financial markets, Goldman kicked off the quarterly reporting period for investment banks with a 38 percent return on equity.

"It puts people's minds at ease," with regard to recent worries, said Sandler O'Neill analyst Jeff Harte, who has a "buy" rating on Goldman shares.

The bank remains the most successful trading house and the most active merger adviser worldwide and has reaped big profits from investing its own money.

Fixed-income currency and commodity trading generated a record $4.6 billion in net revenue, with strong performance across all major businesses.

Goldman also reported $1.73 billion from its investments such as stakes in Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd. (1398.HK), Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (8316.T) and $500 million in gains related to the adoption of a new accounting policy.

"While upside surprises have been the norm for Goldman, we believe the magnitude was probably better than the market expected," Fox-Pitt Kelton analyst David Trone said in a client note.

Viniar told reporters that recent market concerns that subprime woes would hurt Goldman's results were overblown. Indeed, Goldman's fixed income trading was up across the board compared with the fourth quarter.

"Even our mortgage business was up despite the obviously more challenging subprime market," Viniar said. "Mortgage is a strategically important business to Goldman Sachs, but it's still modest in size compared with the overall firm."

Equities trading also posted record revenue of $3.09 billion, up 26 percent amid rising stocks, active clients and gains by the firm's proprietary trades.

Investment banking revenue rose 17 percent to $1.72 billion, including record MA and debt underwriting fees. Goldman this year leads the industry in announced MA transactions worldwide.

Goldman's asset management and securities services arm likewise generated revenue of $1.6 billion. And while managed assets grew 26 percent to a record $719 billion, asset management revenue fell 28 percent to $1.07 billion after poor performance in Goldman's Global Alpha hedge fund last year.

Sandler analyst Harte noted that after the recent pullback, Goldman shares are "actually kind of cheap, given the earnings they're posting." Goldman shares trade at 2.7 times its book value, which rose 6 percent in the quarter, near the upper end of its historic range.

(Additional reporting by Christian Plumb)

entry.headline: Chevron sees output growth from new projects
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) said on Tuesday its new oil and natural gas projects will produce about 1.1 million barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2011, and it will keep exploration spending high in the coming years.

The production from those projects will give the company average annual output growth of at least 3 percent through 2010, it said.

"We are making progress on more than 30 oil and gas development projects that represent a Chevron investment of at least $1 billion each," Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Dave O'Reilly said in a statement issued as part of a Chevron presentation to analysts.

Those projects would contribute to an average proved reserves replacement rate of more than 100 percent for the next five years.

The company had said in February its 2007 production would drop to an average of 2.6 million barrels per day from 2.67 million in 2006.

Spending on exploration would be "at a higher level than it's been in the past," Bobby Ryan, vice president for global exploration, told analysts, although the expected $2 billion in planned spending for 2007 would be less than the 2006 level.

Total capital expenditures for 2007 are still expected to be $19.6 billion, including affiliate spending, with 39 percent of that in North America, 25 percent in Africa, 19 percent in Asia-Pacific, 7 percent in the Caspian region, and 10 percent in the rest of the world.

In its refining operations, Chevron is seeking to add flexibility to its plants to process heavier and higher-sulphur crude oils.

The company said it plans to selectively divest assets, which will give it a more focused footprint with a strong presence in fewer locations.

entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp.'s (CVX.N) Executive Vice President of Upstream and Gas George Kirkland on Tuesday said he is confident the company will replace more oil than it produces over the next five years.

Speaking at the company's analyst meeting in New York, Kirkland also said he expects production in the Caspian region to rise to 400,000 barrels per day in 2008 from about 275,000 barrels per day in 2006.

He expects Chevron's production in West Africa to nearly double by 2012.

entry.headline: Goldman CFO says banking backlog highest since '00
entry.body:
NEW YORK, March 13 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) Chief Financial Officer David Viniar on Tuesday said the firm's backlog of pending merger advisory and underwriting business rose to its highest point since 2000, when the 1990s bull market peaked.

The backlog of pending M, debt and equity underwriting all rose during the fiscal quarter that ended Feb. 23. Viniar, in a briefing with reporters, also said its subprime mortgage business is a relatively modest part of its overall business.

At the same time, though, he noted that subprime mortgages remains a good business and will survive the current shakeout, albeit smaller than it was before the recent downturn. Viniar said that as of right now, problems in the subprime segment have not spread to other markets.

Investors had sold off Goldman shares in recent weeks amid worries that a sell-off in stocks and growing loan defaults in the subprime mortgage market would crimp revenue. Instead, the investment bank reported record revenue and a 29 percent jump in profit.
